texts.mn:
Business Description
Ludev is forty eight years old, a widow, and has two children.  Ludev has five years of shop ownership experience.  Before running his own food shop Ludev worked as a shop assistant for fourteen years.  This is his second loan.  Ludev was only late paying once on his previous loan and this was due to the unexpected cost of his wife’s funeral.   would like this loan to expand the choices his customers have when shopping at his store.  

Бизнес тодорхойлолт 
Бадрал нь 48 настай, энхэргүй, 2 хүүхэдтэй. Бадрал нь 5 жил дэлгүүр ажиллуулсан туршлагатай. Тэрээр хүнсний дэлгүүрээ нээхээс өмнө 14 жилийн турш дэлгүүрийн туслахаар ажилласан. Энэхүү зээл нь ХасБанкнаас авч буй 2 дахь зээл нь юм. Тэрээр өмнөх зээлээ төлөхдөө 1 өдөр хугацаа хэтэрсэн бөгөөд энэ нь  эхнэр нь нас барж оршуулгын зардал гарсантай холбоотой. Бадрал энэхүү зээлээ харилцагчийн сонголтод тулгуурлан өөрийн дэлгүүртээ зарцуулах болно.

loans.use:
Loan Description
Ludev requests a micro loan for 1,000,000 MNT to purchase food for his shop.  Ludev would like to expand his inventory and buy 67 new items.

Зээлийн тодорхойлолт 
Лүдэв овогтой Бадрал нь өөрийн хүнсний дэлгүүрийн эргэлтийн хөрөнгөдөө зориулан 1,000,000 төгрөгийн бичил зээл хүссэн. 67 шинэ төрлийн бүтээгдэхүүн худалдан авах хүсэлтэй байгаа.

loans.name: Sopheak

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheak T., 26, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Phi, 27, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1999 and have two children, a son and a daughter, both of whom are in local school.

Mrs. Sopheak has been selling grocery items for four years. She buys them from the market in Phnom Penh for resale at her shop in front of the house. Bunthoeun is a construction worker who also also fishes and raises cows. Sopheak is requesting a loan of $500 to expand her grocery store and repair her kitchen.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store and repair her kitchen.

loans.name: Loeng

texts.en:
Mrs. Loeng S., a 50-year-old widow, and her daughter, Miss Maly Roeun, 23, live with Loeng’s elderly parents in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh.  Assisted by Maly,

Mrs. Loeng has been selling fruit and sugar cane juice for eight years. She buys a wide variety of produce such as apples, bananas, longan fruit, and oranges from the market in Phnom Penh for resale at her shop in the village market. Now Loeng is requesting a loan of $650 to expand her business and buy one sugar cane juice machine.

loans.use: To expand her business and buy one sugar cane juice machine.

loans.name: Chanry

texts.en: Mrs. Chanry S., 28 and the mother of two preschool children, lives in Pon Ley Village in Kampong Chhnang Province where she is a rice middlewoman who buys rice to later sell at a better price. Since her business has improved, she is requesting a loan to add to her savings to buy more rice to keep in stock. Her husband, Mr. Thea Oeurn, is both a car driver and a pig breeder, but he earns only a small income.  Previously, Mrs. Chanry S. obtained a loan to start the pig breeding business. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more rice to keep in stock.

loans.name: Nasy

texts.en:
Mrs. Nasy S., 42, and her husband, Mr. Hoeun Ham, 43, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh, were married in 1991 and have six sons. Five of them are in local school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Nasy has been a weaver for seventeen years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. Mr. Hoeun has been a cow seller for seven years. Mrs. Nasy now is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase silk materials for weaving and a cow for her husband to resell.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and a cow for resale.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mr. P. Em and his wife, Mrs. Saroeun Mil, who live about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married during the Pol Pot regime and have six children, four sons and two daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the remaining three, one is a security guard, another a garment factory worker, and the last one a student in the local school.

Mr. P. has been a gardener for four years, while his wife is a garment factory worker. The family lives in a Khmer wooden house, but its staircase is old and broken. Therefore he is requesting a loan of $600 to build a new staircase.

loans.use: To build a staircase for his house.

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man L. and his wife, Mrs. Sata Ham, who live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, have been married for 28 years and have 11 children: four sons and seven daughters. Five of their children are married and live outside the family home, while the other six attend the local school.

Assisted by his wife, Mr. Man has been in the recycling business for over 10 years, buying recycling materials from villagers for resale to a middleman, who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Mr. Ma is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase recycling materials for resale.

loans.use: To invest in his recycling business.

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Oeun P., 75, and his wife, Mrs. Ren Phoung, 66, who live about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1956 and have four children, one son and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Another is a fisherman and the fourth a farmer.

Mr. Oeun and his wife have been farming for 28 years. They grow various kinds of vegetables such as spinach, cucumbers, and tomatoes on his farm to sell at the market. Now Oeun is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase seeds and fertilizers for growing vegetables, as well as fishing nets for his son's fishing. The couple is strong enough to work even though they are advancing in years.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers for growing vegetables, as well as fishing nets for his son's fishing.

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mr. H. Sam Bath (not in the picture), 50, and his family live in a small village off of National Road Two, about 15 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. He and his wife, Mrs. Saret Korn (shown in the picture), 48, have been married since 1979 and have eight children, one of whom studies in school. Another three work in nearby garment factories and the other four are married.

Saret has been selling groceries and other household goods from a small stand in front of their house for 10 years, while H. has been driving a motorbike taxi in Phnom Penh for the same amount of time. Phnom Penh may well be one of the world’s largest cities without even one municipal bus. Motorbike taxis and tuk-tuks are the preferred and, with the rare exception of an automobile taxi, the only way to get around. On a good day, H. can make about $6. He is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy a new motorbike for his son-in-law to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his son-in-law to drive to work.

loans.name: Thi Tu

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tu Thi D. is 33 years old. Everyday, she buys crackers and breads in her neighborhood and goes to sell it in adjacent towns. Her husband works in construction. The family’s income is about 200,000 VND per week. She has three children who are in school. She is requesting 2,006,000 VND to use as capital for her business. She would like to participate in the program for a long time and increase the loan amount slowly.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Dương Thị Tú (MS: 020022), năm nay 33 tuổi. Hàng ngày chị đi mua bánh đa bánh, bánh mỳ của các hộ trong thôn đi giao bán ở các địa phương khác. Chồng chị làm nghề xây dựng. Thu nhập gia đình chị khoảng 200.000 VND/ tuần. Chị có ba con còn nhỏ hiện đang đi học. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để thêm vốn đi chợ. Chị thích được tham gia chương trình lâu dài và được vay vốn tăng dần lên.

loans.use: Capital for business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Y

texts.vi:
Mrs. Y Thi N., 31 years old, sells sesame rice crackers as her day job. Besides that she also works the fields and grows colorful flowers to supplement the family’s income. Her husband works in construction, and their average income is 200,000 VND per week. She has 3 children who are still in school. She is requesting 2,006,000 to invest in the business. She hopes to become a long-time participant in the loan program.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Ngô Thị Y (MS: 020025), năm nay 31 tuổi. Hàng ngày chị đi bán bánh đa. N.ài ra chị chị còn làm ruộng và chồng hoa màu để tăng thu nhập cho gia đình. Chồng chị làm xây dựng, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 200.000 VND/ tuần. Chị có ba con hiện đang đi học. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để thêm vốn đi chợ. Chị rất muốn được tham gia chương trình lâu dài.

loans.use: invest in the crackers business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Khanh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Khanh Thi L. is 48 years old. She sells breakfast foods, and her husband works as a guard at a construction site. Besides that, the coupL. also works the fields and grows plants to create more income for the family. Their average income is about 250,000 VND. She is requesting 1,062,000 VND to buy more supplies for the breakfast business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Cô Lê Thị Khánh (MS: 020023), năm nay 48 tuổi. Cô làm nghề bán hàng ăn sáng. Chồng cô làm bảo vệ ở công trình xây dựng. Ngoài ra vợ chồng cô còn làm ruộng và hoa màu để tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Thu nhập của gia đình cô khoảng 250.000 VND. Cô vay 1.062.000 VND để thêm vốn bán hàng.

loans.use: Buy more food supplies

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Adunwole Elizabeth

texts.en:
A. Adunwole Elizabeth is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She is a fashion designer in Badagry, Lagos state, Nigeria. She learned this business in 2 years and has been working for the past 11 years. A. now has 3 sewing machines and 2 apprentices. She also makes bags.

A. has been a leader in a lending group for the past 2 years. She needs a loan of $1,200 USD to buy more tailoring and bag-making materials. She sends a big thank you to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Lan

texts.vi:
Mrs. Lan Thi N., 29 years old, runs a recycling business. Her husband works as a security guard for various companies. Besides her main business, she also runs a general store out of her home. The couple also works the fields where they grow various plants and wheat. The family's income is about 300,000 VND per week. She is requesting 2,006,000 VND to buy more stock for her business and the general store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Lan (MS: 020024), năm nay 29 tuổi. Chị làm nghề buôn bán phế liệu. Chồng chị làm bảo vệ cho các cơ quan. Ngoài việc đi chợ, chị còn mở một của hàng tạp hóa tại nhà. Anh chị cũng nhận ruộng để làm màu và chồng lúa. Thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 VND/ tuần. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để thêm vốn đi chợ và mua hàng tạp hóa.

loans.use: capital for business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Adeeso

texts.en:
M. Adeeso lives in the Iba Housing Estate Ipaye, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells general provisions, including foodstuffs and drinks. She learned this business from her mother and has been working since 1997. M. is business oriented and so she has diversified into a new but related business—the sale of provisions in bulk, including palm oil in gallons and drinks in cartons. She is 39 years old and married with 4 children.

M. has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She now needs a loan of $875 USD to buy more inventory. She says thank you to all who make the loan possible.

loans.use: Sales of foodstuffs, provisions and drinks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Hang's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Hang (ID number: 060005) is 32 years old. She used the first loan to purchase more beans and soy beans to make tofu and bean sprouts. She realised that as her inventory expanded, she was able to save more and her daily income increased because she had more stocks to sell. Thus, she would like to request for a second loan. Her group had already repaid the first loan fully. This time, she wants to borrow 2,714,000VND to purchase more beans and soy beans. Her husband also helps out with the business to earn more profits. They have three school-going children. Their average daily income is 120,000VND (about 8USD). Her group also consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Nhi (ID number: 060007), borrows 2,714,000VND to purchase more stocks for her general store. She joined in the first time and repaid fully.

Mrs. N. Thi Hong (ID number: 060019), borrows 2,714,000VND to purchase more eggs to sell. She joined in the first time and repaid fully.

Mrs. M. Thi Dat (ID number: 060020), borrows 2,714,000VND to breed pigs. She joined in the first time and repaid fully.

Mrs. N. Thi Loan (ID number: 060021), borrows 2,714,000VND to purchase more eggs to sell. She joined in the first time and repaid fully.

Mrs. N. Thi Tham (ID number: 060026), borrows 2,006,000VND to purchase more stocks for her general store.

Mrs. N. Thi Nhi (ID number: 060027), borrows 2,006,000VND to purchase pig feeds.

The total amount requested is 1,050USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Ngô Thị Hằng (MS: 060005), năm nay 32 tuổi. Lần một chị vay về mua thêm đỗ làm giá đỗ, đậu phục vụ chăn nuôi. Chị thấy mình có thêm vốn và tiết kiệm được hơn, mức thu nhập trên ngày cũng cao hơn vì chị có nhiều hàng hơn để bán. Chị thấy thích và tiếp tục tham gia lần hai. Chị và cả nhóm đã hoàn trả xong rất tốt lần một. Lần hai chị vay 2.714.000 để đầu tư vào việc mua giá đỗ làm đậu giá. Chồng chị cũng giúp chị trong việc đi chợ để có thêm thu nhập. Gia đình chị có ba con hiện còn đang đi học. Múc thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 120.000 VND/ ngày. Trong nhóm còn có:

  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Nhị (MS: 060007), vay 2.714.000 VND để mua bán hàng tiêu dùng. Chị đã tham gia ở kỳ trước và đã trả hết.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng (MS: 060019), vay 2.714.000 VND để bổ xung vốn buôn bán trứng. Chị đã tham gia ở kỳ trước và đã hoàn trả hết.
  • Chị Mẫn Thị Đạt (MS: 060020), vay 2.714.000 VND để lấy vốn chăn nuôi lợn. Chị đã tham gia vay ở kỳ trước và đã trả hết.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Loan (MS: 060021), vay 2.714.000 VND để đi mua bán trứng. Chị đã tham gia ở kỳ trước và đã trả hết.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Thẩm (MS: 060026), vay 2.006.000 VND để mua bán hàng tiêu dùng.
  • Chị Mẫn Thị Linh (MS: 060027), vay 2.006.000 VND để lấy vốn mua cám chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: Retail and agriculture

loans.name: Thi Minh's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. D. Thi Minh (ID number: 13050028) is 24 years old. Though young, she is very active and diligent. She lives with her husband, her parents-in-law and her three young children. Her husband works as a plumber. Apart from managing the general store at home, Mrs. Minh also performs agricultural tasks. Her family's income is quite stable at 200,000VND per day (about 13USD). She has never borrowed from anywhere else, but because she likes the fact that she can repay on an installment basis through this Fund, she would like to borrow 2,006,000VND to expand her store. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. D. Thi Duyen (ID number: 13050027), borrows 2,006,000VND to invest in her souvenir shop.

Mrs. N. Thi Quynh (ID number: 13050029), borrows 2,006,000VND for her husband to purchase more woods to make furniture.

Mrs. D. Thi Hien (ID number: 13050030), borrows 2,006,000VND for her husband to expand his construction business.

Mrs. N. Thi Hanh (ID number: 13050031), borrows 2,006,000VND to purchase more stocks for her grocery store.

The total amount requested is 600USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Đinh Thị Minh (MS: 13050028), năm nay 24 tuổi. Là người còn trẻ nhưng chị rất năng động và chăm chỉ. Vợ chồng chị sống cùng bố mẹ chồng và ba con nhỏ. Chồng chị là thợ lắp điện nước. Chị ngoài việc bán hàng tạp hóa tại nhà, chị còn làm ruộng. Thu nhập của gia đình chị khá ổn định khoảng 200.000 VND/ ngày. Chị chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu nhưng vì thích hình thức tiết kiệm để hoàn trả của chương trình nên đã tham gia vay 2.006.000 VND để mở rộng của hàng. Các thành viên khác trong nhóm là: Chị Đinh Thị Duyên (MS: 13050027), vay 2.006.000 VND để thêm vốn mở rộng của hàng bán hàng lưu niệm. Chị Nguyễn Thị Quỳnh (MS: 13050029), vay 2.006.000 VND để chồng chị mua gỗ đóng bàn ghế bán. Chị Đinh Thị Hiền (MS: 13050030), vay 2.006.000 VND để chồng chị phát triển nghề xây dựng. Chị Nghiêm Thị Thanh (MS: 13050031), vay 2.006.000 VND để buôn bán mỳ, giá, đỗ.

loans.use: Retail

loans.name: Thi Thuy

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Thuy (ID number: 11030025), 28 years old, is very hard-working and active. Apart from performing agricultural tasks, she also has a general store at home, selling food stuff, fruits, and other things. Her husband makes souvenirs for a living. She has never requested for loans before. Now, she wants to borrow 2,006,000VND (125USD) to purchase more stocks for her general store. Her family's average weekly income is about 300,000VND (approximately 19USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Thùy (MS: 11030025), năm nay 28 tuổi. Chị là người chăm chỉ, năng động. Ngoài làm ruộng chị còn bán hàng tạp hóa, thực phẩm, hoa quả tại nhà. Chồng chị làm đồ mỹ nghệ. Trước đây chị chưa tùng vay vốn. Nay chị tham gia chương trình với mức vốn 2.006.000 VND để bổ sung vốn bán hàng. Thu nhập gia đình chị khoảng 300.000 VND/ tuần.

loans.use: Invest in general store

loans.name: Itamakinde

texts.en:
S. Itamakinde sells clothes, shoes, and bags and also makes beaded jewelry. She has been in this business since 2000. S. lives in the Iba housing estate, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 33 years old and married with 2 children.

S. needs a loan amount of $875 USD to buy more clothes, shoes and bags for sale. She says thank you to all who make the loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Thi Chat's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Chat (ID number: 11030007) is 61 years old. Her group had repaid the first loan fully and would like to request for a second loan. Mrs. Chat is a retiree. She is currently living with her husband and son. She borrowed 2,006,000VND in the first loan for her son to expand his mechanic business. This time, she wants to borrow 2,478,000VND to further invest in this mechanic business. Her group consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Tam (ID number: 11030008), borrows 2,006,000VND to expand her furniture-making business.

Mr. N. Huu Thang (ID number: 11030019), borrows 2,478,000VND to purchase pigs to breed.

Mrs. P. Thi Bich Thuy (ID number: 11030010), borrows 2,478,000VND to invest in her furniture-making business.

Mrs. N. Thi Dung (ID number: 11030021), borrows 1,534,000VND to raise cows and chickens.

Mrs. N. Thi Son (ID number: 11030009), borrows 1,062,000VND to purchase more stocks for her general store.

The total amount requested is 725USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by P. Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Nguyễn Thị Chắt (MS: 11030007), năm nay 61 tuổi. Nhóm cô đều đã hoàn thành tốt kỳ một và chuyển sang kỳ hai. Là cán bộ về hưu, hiện cô đang sống cùng chồng và người con trai. Kỳ trước với 2.006.000 VND vay của chương trình, cô đã có thêm vốn cho con trai phát triển và mở rộng nghề cơ khí. Lần này cô vay 2.478.000 VND cũng để mở rộng nghề làm cơ khí. Các thành viên khác trong nhóm: Chị Nguyễn Thị Tám (MS: 11030008), vay 2.006.000 VND để phát triển nghề mộc. Anh Nguyễn Hữu Thắng (MS: 11030019) vay 2.478.000 VND để mua lợn giống. Chị Phạm Thị Bích Thủy (MS: 11030010), vay 2.478.000 VND để thêm vốn sản xuất đồ gỗ. Chị Nguyễn Thị Dùng (MS: 11030021), vay 1.534.000 VND để chăn nuôi bò, gà. Chị Nguyễn Thị Sơn (MS: 11030009), vay 1.062.000 VND để thêm vốn bán hàng.

loans.use: Retail and agriculture

loans.name: Akinsanyan

texts.en:
Akinsanyan R. lives in the Iba housing estate, Ipaye, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells textiles, headgear, women's clothing, and the traditional Yoruba woven fabric known as "aso oke." After learning the business from her mother -in –law, Akinsayan opened her own business 10 years ago. Akinsanyan is 52years old and married with 4 children.

Akinsanyan has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She now needs a loan of $1,200 USD to buy add shoes, bags and aso oke to her inventory. She expresses her gratitude to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Gift

texts.en: Gift S. is a hair stylist and she also sells weave-ons and other hair attachments. She learned this business for 3 years and has been in this business since 1998. Gift is 29 years old and married with three children.  She lives in Ojo Igbede, Lagos State, Nigeria. Gift has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years.  She needs a loan of $700 USD to buy more weave-ons, hair attachments and to introduce the sale of rechargeable phone cards. This, she believes, will increase her profits and it will have a positive effect on her family. she thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more weave-ons and hair attachments

loans.name: Thi Yen's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Yen (ID number: 070034), 54 years old, would like to borrow 2,714,000 VND to invest in her eatery. Her group had already borrowed one time before and repaid fully. The loan enabled her to purchase more stocks and thus, her daily profit was higher than before. She was able to save for her family. She has one child who is attending college. Her family's average daily income is about 100,000 VND (about 6.5 USD). Her group consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Dinh (ID number: 070035), borrows 2,478,000 VND to purchase more woods to make furniture.

Mrs. N. Thi Hien (ID number: 070036), borrows 2,478,000vVND to purchase more woods to make furniture.

Mrs. N. Thi Le (ID number: 070038), borrows 2,478,000 VND to invest in her butcher shop.

Mrs. N. Thi Hoi (ID number: 070039), borrows 2,478,000 VND to purchase more rice to make cake.

Mrs. N. Thi Son (ID number: 070042), borrows 2,006,000 VND to breed chickens and pigs.

Mrs. N. Thi Linh (ID number: 070043), borrows 2,006,000 VND to purchase more construction materials to sale.

The total amount requested is 1,050.00 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Nguyễn Thi Yên (MS: 070034), năm nay 54 tuổi. Vay 2.714.000 VND về bán hàng ăn. Cô cùng nhóm đã vay được một chu kỳ và hoàn trả xong. Lần một cô vay về mua được nhiều hàng hơn nên mức lãi hàng ngày cô thu được nhiều hơn. Cô đã tiết kiệm được hơn cho gia đình. Cô có một con đang đi học cao đẳng. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình cô khoảng 100.000 VND/ngày. Trong nhóm cô còn có: Chị Nguyễn Thị Dinh (MS: 070035), vay 2.478.000 VND để bổ sung vốn mua gỗ đóng bàn ghế. Chị Nghiêm Thị Hiền (MS: 070036), vay 2.478.000 VND mua gỗ đóng bàn ghế. Chị Nguyễn Thị Lệ (MS: 070038), vay 2.478.000 VND để bổ sung vốn buôn bán thịt lợn. Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồi (MS: 070039), vay 2.478.000 VND để mua gạo làm bánh. Chị Nguyễn Thị Sơn (MS: 070042), vay 2.006.000 VND về chăn nuôi gà lợn. Chị Nguyễn Thị Lĩnh (MS: 070043), vay 2.006.000 VND bổ xung vốn mua vật liệu xây dựng bán.

loans.use: Retail and agriculture

loans.name: Thi So

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi So (ID number: 070044), is 46 years old. She would like to borrow 2,006,000 VND (125 USD) to purchase seeds and fertiliser for farming. She has 3 school-going children. Her husband is a manual worker moving wood blocks to earn a stable income for their family. Her family's average income is 80,000 VND (about 5 USD). Mrs. So has never borrowed from any other Fund. She likes to join this Fund because the procedure is simple.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Nguyễn Thị Sổ (MS: 070044), năm nay 46 tuổi. vay 2.006.000 VND về mua lân đạm, giống phục vụ nông nghiệp. Cô có 3 con còn đang đi học. Chồng cô đi bốc vác gỗ giúp cho gia đình có thu nhập thường xuyên. Mức thu nhập của gia đình là 80.000 VND. Gia đình cô chưa vay vốn ở đâu. Cô thích tham gia vì thủ tục đơn giản.

loans.use: Farming

loans.name: Ayinla

texts.en:
Ayinla C. lives in Egun, Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells clothing fabric. She studied this business for six months and has been selling on her own since 2005. C. is 52 years old and married with five children.

C. needs a loan of $425 USD to buy more fabric. She is grateful to Kiva and LAPO Microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi A. is 36 years old and married with two children. She has been selling cooked foods and drinks for the past 7 years in Igando, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Kemi needs a loan of US$1,200 to buy more drinks and foodstuffs for her restaurant. Kemi expresses her gratitude to kiva and lenders.

loans.use: To buy more food and beverages

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Believe in God is the name of this group and its members are Ramatu C. and Ramatu K.. The former sells local produce, such as palm kernels and rice. The latter sells firewood. Firewood is used extensively for cooking in almost every household in Sierra Leone.

This group is seeking a loan of Le 2,000,000.00 to expand their businesses. These women have been with SMT for over a year now and have always repaid their loans successfully. Ramatu C. was born in Magburaka about 30 miles from Makeni City. She stays with her husdand and four children in Makeni. She has been in the local produce business for over ten years now.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm-oil, palm kernels, and firewood.

loans.name: Mame

texts.fr:
Mame D., age 49, is  married and has four children in her care.  She has been a member of the village bank of Château d’eau Bignona for three years.  She does business in shoes and second-hand clothing next to the TOTAL station.  Mame buys merchandise in Dakar for resale in Bignona.  She want to bolster her business to better help her family.    The loan that she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

 Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer


Mame D., 49 ans, mariée avec 04 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Château d’eau Bignona depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle fait un commerce de friperies et de chaussures à coté de la station TOTAL. Mame achète la marchandise à Dakar pour revendre à Bignona Elle veut renforcer son activité pour mieux aider sa famille. Le  prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy and resell second-hand clothing and shoes

loans.name: Afolabi

texts.en:
F. Afolabi makes interior decorations such as curtains and bed sheets. She studied this craft for a year and has been in business since 2006. F. lives in Egun, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 41 years old and married with 5 children.

F. requests a loan of US$875 to buy more curtains, curtain poles, and bed sheets. She sends a big thank you to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more interior decorations and bed sheets for sales.

loans.name: Fight For Progress Group

texts.en:
The members of this group are Fatmata K., Rosaline K., and Memuna K.. They named their group Fight for Progress. Members of this group sell palm-oil, which is considered a very lucrative business among women in Sierra Leone. Palm-oil is used in the preparation of almost all kinds of food, making soaps, and some kinds of medicines.

These business women would like to be loaned the sum of Le 3,000,000.00 to help themselves go further afield to purchase more gallons of palm-oil.

Fatmata, who is the leader of this group, has been in the palm-oil business for two years now. She is 38, married to a farmer, and they have three children.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm-oil to expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Oyekola

texts.en: Oyekola M. owns a fish farm (pond). She learned this business  for 3 months and she started her own fish pond 2 years ago. Oyekola M. is 43 years old and married with 4 children. She needs a loan of US$1,200 to buy more fingerlings (small fish). This will increase her production and thereby increase her profit margin by having more fish for sale.

loans.use: To buy more fingerlings (small fish)

loans.name: Honesty Group

texts.en:
This group is called Honesty and its leader is Dauda S.. He sells dishes. The other members of the group are Abubakarr Seasy, who sells different sorts of articles, Fatmata S., who sells local produce, and Jatu S., who sells dishes.

The group is requesting the sum of Le 4,000,000.00. This can go a long way in helping them expand their businesses, increasing sales and profit. This group has been with SMT for over two years now and loans have been very helpful keeping them in business.

Their leader, Dauda, is now 38, born in Makeni, and is married with three children.

loans.use: To buy more dishes, articles, and local produce to expand their businesses.

loans.name: Saly

texts.fr:
Saly M., age 53, is married and has four children in her care. She has been an energetic member of the village bank of Bignona Bassène for three and a half years. Her business consists of buying and reselling honey, lemons, and brooms. The income derived from her commerce enables her to help cover family expenses and medical care. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Saly M., 53 ans, mariée avec 04 enfants en charge est une membre dynamique du banc villageois de Bignona Bassène depuis 3 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre du miel, du citron et des balaies. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer à la dépense familiale et aux soins médicaux. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy and resell honey, lemons, brooms, and nététou (a spicy seasoning)

loans.name: Olawale

texts.en:
Olawale F. designs and sells clothes. She studied this business for 5 years and has been working since 1992. Olawale is 35 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Egan, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Olawale has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past year. She now needs a loan of US$875 to buy an embroidery machine and a generator so that she can meet the demands of her increasing customers.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine and a generator

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor is a 28 year old father of one. He has run a charcoal business for the past five years. He does his business inthe Chanika area, and gets his charcoal by burning trees in the nearby forest. Because of the ongoing government restriction on deforestation, he is slowly starting up a grocery alongside with the charcoal business. He is in need of a loan to help his expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business selling charcoal and groceries.

loans.name: Salim Saleh

texts.en: Salim is a 46 year old resident of Chanika in the Dar Es Salaam area. He has been in business for the past 15 years. Recently he has run a small poultry farm, where he has up to 150 broilers and layers. He supplies eggs for the nearby restaurants. The profits have helped him put all his kids to school and build a new house. He is in need of a loan to help him expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his poultry farm.

loans.name: Latifat

texts.en:
Latifat M. owns a fish pond in which she rears fingerlings into adult fish for sale. She studied this business for one year and has been operating her pond since 2006. Latifat is 34 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Egan, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Latifat has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She needs a loan of $1,200 to buy more fingerlings and feed, which she says will enable her to produce more fish for sale.

loans.use: To stock a fish pond

loans.name: Hai Seminary 2029-1 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Magreat D.. She currently sells bread at the shop and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Magreat is 27 years old and is married to a shop keeper. She has five children, ranging from age 6 to 19, all of whome go to school. Each week, Magreat makes approximately 400 Sudanese pounds in profit. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

Magreat is joined in her small group by Hellen J., Karamela K., Rose K., and Loice V.. Hellen sells charcoal and wants to open up a shop. Karamela sells bread at the market and wants a loan to open up a restaurant. Rose sells beer and wants to construct a shop. Loice sells bread and is requesting a loan to build an oven.

loans.use: To expand her business selling bread.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Wafanya Kazi Group

texts.en: These are a group of five who have been together as a group for the past two years. They all sell fresh fish from the ocean in KIgamboni. The men sometime go fishing and do the selling as well. They are all in need of a loan to help the expand there business.

loans.use: To expand business their businesses selling fresh fish.

loans.name: Block C North 2003-2 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Rose F.. She currently sells beer and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Rose is 30 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children, ranging from age 7 to 15, all of whom go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately 80 Sudanese pounds in profit. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to open up a bar.

Rose is joined in her small group by Poni S., Juru L., Ruth K., and Jane A.. Poni sells vegetables at the market (like okra and cabbages) and wants to expand her business. Juru sells charcoal at home and wants a loan to pay school fees for her children. Ruth sells bread at the market and wants to build an oven. Jane sells beans and posho at the market and is requesting a loan to open up a bar.

loans.use: To open up a bar.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana A. lives at Igando, Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells drugs, provisions, and drinks. She learned this business for 3 years and started her own business in 1997. Christiana is 30 years old and married with 3 children. Christiana has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years.  She needs a loan of US$875 to buy more drugs, provisions, and drinks. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more drugs, provisions, and drinks

loans.name: Babalola

texts.en:
A. Babalola is 34 years old and married with 4 children. She sells rice to neighboring markets and other small entrepreneurs in her community. She learned this business for 4 years and opened her own shop 12 years ago. 
Babalola needs a loan of US$1,200 to buy more bags of rice so that she can meet the demands of her numerous customers.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Wan Word Movement Group

texts.en:
The members of this group are all local entrepreneurs based in Makeni City, the Northern Provincial Headquarter. The members of the group are Aminata K., M`Balu T., and Hawanatu K.. They are requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000.00 to help them boost their businesses. The leader of the group, Amimata, sells plastic containers (or "rubbers" as they are locally called here), M`Balu sells clothes, and Hawanatu sells palm-oil.

They named their group, Wan Word Movement. This is Krio, meaning One Word Movement, that is, they are ready to agree with each other.

The group leader, Amimata, is 39, she has two children, and a husband who is currently working in the mines.

loans.use: To buy more goods for the business.

loans.name: Block C Nime A 2037-3 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Cicilia L.. She is currently sells cosmetics at the market and is requesting a loan to construct houses for rent. Cicilia is 35 years old and married to a peasant. She has six children, ranging from age 5 to 18, all of whom go to school. Each week, Cicilia makes approximately 100 sudanese pounds in profit. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to construct houses for rent.

Cicilia is joined in her small group by Karkic J., Karla A., Paida M., and Loice B.. Karkic sells beer and wants to open up a shop. Karla sells bread and wants a loan to construct an oven. Paida sells beans at the market and wants to expand the business. Loice sells sugar and beans and is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To construct houses to rent.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Babalola

texts.en:
K. Babalola lives at Igando, Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells bags of rice. She learned this business for 3 years and opened her own shop 2 years ago. She is 32 years old and married with 2 children.

Babalola has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She needs a loan of US$1,200 to increase the size of her inventory of bags of rice so that she can increase her sales and profit. She expresses her thanks to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Hai Seminary Merikolong 2044-4 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Fibi K.. She currently sells posho and beans and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Fibi is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children, ranging from age 6 to 16, all of whom go to school. Each week, Fibi makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profit and hopes to open up a shop with the extra capital from her loan.

Fibi is joined in her small group by MaK. O., Baronica K., Voulale E., and Lona J.. MaK. sells bread and wants to buy an oven. Baronica sells vegetables and wants a loan to pay school fees. Voulale E. sells charcoal and wants to expand the business. Lona sells bread and is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To open up a shop.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ngagne

texts.fr:
This traveling salesman has substantial business experience. He wants to increase his supply of products and improve his profits. By doing so, Mr. F. will be able to take care of his family and meet their essential needs.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Ce commerçant ambulant a une solide expérience du commerce. Il veut renforcer son stock et améliorer ses bénéfices. Avec cette activité NGagne arrive à entretenir sa famille et faire face à l'essentiel de ses besoins.

loans.use: Small business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace E. sells foodstuffs. She learned this business for 3 weeks and started her own business in 2008. Grace is 39 years old and married with 3 children, she lives in lagos State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of US$875 to buy more foodstuffs for sale. She says thanks  to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Ogeleyinbo

texts.en: M. Ogeleyinbo sells provisions and foodstuffs in Isheri olofin, Lagos State, Nigeria.  She is 41 years old and married with 4 children.  M. learned the grocery business from her sister over a period of 3 years and has been in the business since 2004.  She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She needs a loan of US$425 to buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sale. She is grateful to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more grocery inventory

loans.name: Block B North B 2031-5 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Rejoice L.. She sells sorgurm and is requesting a loan to pay school fees. Rejoice is 42 years old and married to a shopkeeper. She has five children, ranging from age 9 to 24, all of whom go to school. Each week, Rejoice makes approximately 200 Sudanese pounds in profit, and with the extra capital from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees.

Rejoice is joined in her small group by Lusia J., Foyiba F., Eva S., and Elizabeth M.. Lusia sells vegetables at the market and wants to open up a shop. Foyiba sells groudnut paste at the market and wants a loan to expand her business. Eva sells charcoal and wants to expand the business. Elizabeth sells dry fish at the market and is requesting a loan to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To pay school fees.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Adewole

texts.en: B. Adewole is 31 years old and married with a child; she lives at Igando, Lagos State, Nigeria. She learned how to manufacture nylon for four years and she has been producing and supplying nylon at Iyanagbaja community for the past 7 years. B. has been a LAPO client for the past 2 years. She  needs a loan of US$875 to buy more raw materials for nylon production.  She expresses her thanks to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for nylon production

loans.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman is married and has a 2-year-old son. His family lives in Drogobych. Roman works in the sphere of transportation services and travels all over the territory of Ukraine. His business does well because Roman works only uses new vans and which helps him save on maintenance costs. They do occasionally require repair work. He launched his venture only 3 months ago, and he already has about $3000 of gross income. More than $15,000 has been invested in assets. 

One of Roman’s plans is to get official permission to travel to Lviv and back. Obtaining this permission is pretty difficult as it requires much paperwork. However, Roman is not the kind of person who backs off and gives in to circumstances. He is willing to persist and get all the documents needed to be able to expand his business and increase his income as a result. Roman is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas to repair his vehicle so he can take advantage of his new travel permission.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle

loans.name: Block C Nime A 2037-6 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Mania Palista. Currently, she sells local brew at home and is requesting a loan to buy livestock. Mania is 40 years old and married to a peasant. She has three children, ranging from age 7 to 20, all of whom go to school. Each week, Mania makes approximately 80 Sudanese pounds in profit and, with the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to start a livestock business.

Mania is joined in her small group by Agnes J., Mary P., and Anjuka A.. Agnes sells vegetables at the market and wants to buy charcoal to sell. Mary sells bread and paste at the market and wants a loan to open up restaurant. Anjuka sells groundnut at the market and wants to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy livestock and other items to expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC South Sudan - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Vitalyi

texts.en:
Vitalyi is a married man and a father of two kids. His family lives in Nikipol where he sells assorted children’s wear in the central city market. His business is characterized by nice selection of merchandise and affordable prices. Vitalyi has been working in this trade for 2 years. Currently, his monthly turnover capital is about $1500. 

One of Vitalyi’s dreams was to purchase a private house for his family one day. He believed persistent work and higher sales would help him generate enough profit and make enough savings to make this dream come true. His determination was generously repaid and he finally was able to buy a house for his family of 4. Vitalyi is hoping to continue developing his trade with the help of a 2500 Grivna loan.

Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for a new vending facility

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Shoppers who pass Lubov’s neatly arranged retail space at the central city market in Nikopol will find an attractive selection of linen sheets,  towels, household supplies,  and everal choices in terry cloth robes for sale. She has had her own business for three years, and it has provided much needed income to support her family. Lubov currently has around $800 in inventory. 

Lubov is requesting a loan to purchase necessary inventory for the summer, which is a very profitable season for her business. Profits received from this loan will help her open additional vending locations and pay for a refrigerator she has just bought. We are happy for this opportunity to help Lubov improve her business and livelihood.

loans.use: To increase seasonal stock

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is married and has three grown children. Nearly 3 years ago she decided to open a little children’s clothing kiosk, a business she says was her calling. She was able to purchase a kiosk in the very center of the market that is easily accessible to many shoppers. Today, Elvira’s business yields $1000 a month in income with an investment of $2,000 in inventory. 

Elvira sees a great opportunity for business growth this summer season. Her expertise in quality clothing merchandise is greatly appreciated by her customers, and her desire to assist clients and her entrepreneurial spirit are part of what makes her business successful. On a personal level, Elvira desires to invest her earned profits into repair work in her house. She is requesting a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to broaden the assortment of clothing items she offers at her kiosk so she will be ready for the busy season. She has proven to be a strong and reliable client with “Nadiya Ukraine”. We believe that this loan will be a big help to Elvira as she looks for ways to increase her business activity.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility

loans.name: Olesya

texts.en:
Olesya is single. She lives in Simferopol, Crimean peninsula, and works in family business selling kitchen appliances and stoves. Olesya believes that one of the biggest advantages of her work is wholesale prices and relevance to the market demand. 

Olesya has been in business only for one year. However, her attentiveness and creativity have already helped her develop a good understanding of what her clients need and want. They always feel complimented when she goes out of her way to help them with their selections. This has naturally boosted Olesya’s sales and led to growth in her business. Today Olesya is requesting a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to purchase 10 kitchen exhaust fans that are in high demand this season. The loan will enable her to significantly expand her business by being able to supply new clients. Olesya is hoping to reinvest her income into further expansion of her business and remodeling of her family’s apartment. She believes that consistent growth will help her provide a stable source of income and continue to secure her family’s well-being.

loans.use: To increase  stock

loans.name: José Noé

texts.es:
The immense longing to see his children have a promising future is reason enough to motivate José to work hard and to put forth his best effort. He is 58-years-old, and he leaves his house very early in the morning to carry out long hours of hard work with his indispensable companion, his car, with which he offers a taxi service. Thanks to his effort and dedication that he always puts into his work, he is able to offer an education to his young children with satisfaction. José how needs to repair his car because through the years and unstoppable daily route, his only work tool has mechanical failures that make it impossible for it to continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Las inmensas ganas de ver a sus hijos con un futuro prometedor, son razones suficientes que motivan a esforzarse y poner lo mejor de sí a don José, hombre de 58 años, quien desde muy temprano de la mañana abandona su hogar para desempeñar horas de ardua labor con su indispensable compañero, su automóvil, con el que brinda el servicio de taxi. Gracias al esfuerzo, empeño y dedicación que siempre puso en su trabajo, viene brindándole con satisfacción los estudios respectivos a sus menores hijos. Don José ahora necesita refaccionar su auto, ya que por los años y el imparable recorrido diario, su única herramienta de trabajo, ha presentado fallas mecánicas que le imposibilita continuar.

loans.use: To repair his car to continue offering his taxi service.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. sells plates, saucepans, and other kitchen utensils. She is single, and her income is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 4 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional kitchen utensils to expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris A. sells clothing that she has sewn, as well as fabric. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Doris and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: As additional capital to expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Diana Jacquelina

texts.es:
Diana is a diligent and enterprising mother and a native of the capital city of Lima. Since she married her hard-working husband Andres, they found the need to leave her native city to find better opportunities for work. This enterprising couple currently resides in the section of Puno. Andres works as a laborer in an established mine and together, with their persistence, they live trying to improve their quality of life and above all to provide tranquility for thier two young children who motivate them to get ahead. Diana previously dedicated herself to making beautiful and stylish clothing. Now that she lives in Puno she does not have sufficient prime material to continue with this work, for this she needs your help.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Diana es una diligente y emprendedora madre, natural de la ciudad capital Lima, desde que contrajo matrimonio con su laborioso esposo, Andrés, se vieron en la necesidad de abandonar su ciudad natal y buscar mejores oportunidades de trabajo. Esta emprendedora pareja actualmente radica en el departamento de Puno. Andrés trabaja como obrero en una reconocida mina de dicha ciudad y juntos, con empeño, vienen logrando mejorar su calidad de vida y sobre todo, la tranquilidad de sus 2 menores hijos, quienes son las personas que les motivan a seguir adelante. Diana anteriormente estaba dedicada a la confección de hermosas y novedosas prendas de vestir, ahora que radica en este departamento no posee suficiente materia prima para continuar con su labor, para ello, necesita de su apoyo.

loans.use: Investment capital to make clothing.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en:
Abigail L. sells drinks. She is single, and her income does not sufficiently cover her expenses. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.
She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional drinks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Susana Aída

texts.es:
Susana is a hardworking woman. With the help of her husband, who works as a miner, she was able to open a small store and achieve her dream of having her own business without having to leave her work in the country. Susana now wants to set up a space with arcade games for the diversion of her neighbors. This way she can set up a new project with her oldest son who helps her in his free time when he’s not studying. One of her limitations is that she does not have sufficient money to defray the costs of this project. We therefore hope that you can help with Susana’s request.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

Susana es una mujer muy trabajadora que con el apoyo de su esposo, quien trabaja como minero, pudo abrir una pequeña tienda, y consolidar su sueño de un negocio propio, sin dejar de lado el trabajo en el campo. Sin embargo, Susana ahora desea poder tener aparte, un espacio con juegos de tragamonedas para la distracción de sus vecinos y así iniciar un nuevo proyecto junto a su hijo mayor quien le ayuda las veces que está libre y fuera de sus estudios. Pero una de sus limitaciones es que no cuenta con el dinero suficiente para costear los gastos de este proyecto. Esperamos entonces que usted pueda atender la solicitud de doña Susana.

loans.use: Investment capital for a new project.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Elodia

texts.es:
Elodia works as a domestic employee and her husband is an electrician. The loan would purchase work tools for her husband in order to improve their income since they have two school-age children.

Her home is located in the Irpavi II district of La Paz. They do not have their own residence since she lives as a caregiver.

This is the fifth time she has requested a loan, and the third time she has needed the support of Kiva. Her record qualifies her as a #1 client in the payment of her installments.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Elodia trabaja como empleada domestica y su esposo es electricista y el crédito será destinado para la compra de herramientas de trabajo para su esposo y asi mejorar sus ingresos ya que tienen dos hijos en edad escolar.

Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz, no cuenta con una vivienda propia por lo cual vive como cuidadora.

Es la quinta vez que solicita un crédito, y la tercera vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de sus cuotas.

loans.use: Purchase of tools for her husband's electrician business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Justina is a domestic employee, and her husband drives a dump truck to transport sand and bricks. The requested credit will go towards maintenance for the dump truck (purchase of tires and general maintenance) to maintain their level of income, and ideally to increase it.

Their home is located in the zone of Irpavi II in the city of La Paz. She doesn't have her own home, so she cares for one in exchange for not paying rent.

This is the fifth time that she is requesting a loan from Impro, and the third time that she needs Kiva's support. Her history of repaying her loans is very good.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Justina es empleada domestica y su esposo es chofer ya que conduce una volqueta pata transportar arena y ladrillos, y el crédito que ahora solicitan será destinado para el mantenimiento de su volqueta (Compra de llantas y mantenimiento en general) para mantener su nivel de ingresos y en el mejor de los casos mejorarlo. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz, No cuenta con un domicilio por lo que cuida una casa a cambio de no pagara alquileres.

Es la quinta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la tercera vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva su historial la califica como cliente bueno es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su obligación.

loans.use: Maintenance of their dump truck and purchase of tires

loans.name: Teodolinda Magdalena

texts.es:
Teodolinda, at 20 years of age, had to overcome her husband's infidelity. He abandoned her and left her alone with two children, but thanks to the support of her parents, she was able to get ahead and start a business selling sweets. Her parents' house is very close to the school in town, which improved the possibility of her business being succesful. Nevertheless, Teo hopes to be able to grow her business and to sell basic supplies in addition to sweets, so her customers are not only children. For this, she will need to buy new merchandeis that covers the needs of her neighbors.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Teodolinda, a los 20 años tuvo que superar el engaño de su pareja quien la abandonó, dejándola sola con dos hijos, pero gracias al apoyo de sus padres puedo salir adelante y poner un pequeño negocio de dulces. La casa de sus padres es muy cercana a la escuela del pueblo y esto mejoró la posibilidad de que su negocio tenga éxito, sin embargo, Teo espera ahora poder incrementar su negocio y además de dulces, vender también víveres y productos de primera necesidad para que sus clientes no sean sólo los niños. Para ello necesita comprar nueva mercadería que cubra las expectativas de sus vecinos.

loans.use: To acquire new merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria is dedicated to selling food at bus stop 248 in the Irpavi II zone. Her husband is a bricklayer. Their home is located in the Flor de Irpavi zone in the city of La Paz.

This is the fourth time that she is requesting a loan from Impro and the second time that she needs Kiva's support.

The credit will go towards purchasing supplies (rice, noodles, potatoes, and vegetables) and being able to reduce her costs and increase her income. This will help her improve her quality of life and that of her children. She has five children, two who are school-aged and three who are in college.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Victoria se dedica a la venta de comida en la parada del minibús 248 de la zona de irpavi II y su esposo es albañil. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Flor de Irpavi de la ciudad de La Paz.

Es la cuarta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, y la segunda vez que requiere el apoyo de Kiva.

El crédito será destinado para la compra de insumos (Arroz, fideo, papa, y verdura en general) y poder reducir sus costos y aumentar sus ingresos, esto le ayudara a mejorar su calidad de Vida y subsistencia de sus hijos ya que cuenta con cinco hijos dos en edad escolar y tres en edad universitaria.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies like rice, noodles, potatoes, and vegetables for her food sales business.

loans.name: Roger

texts.es:
Roger does welding work and makes metal bars to go over windows. He is a widow and has two small children. He is the only one who generates income in his family.

His home is located in the Irpavi II zone in the city of La Paz. He doesn't have his own house, so he lives in a rental house.

This is the first time that he is requesting a credit. It will go towards working capital (purchase of iron and electrodes). Because of his analysis and cash flow, Roger meets the conditions to pay back this first loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Roger, realiza trabajos de soldadura y elaboración de ventanas metálicas, es viudo y tiene dos hijos pequeños, es el único que genera ingresos en su familia.

Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz. Y no cuenta con casa propia por lo cual vive en alquiler.

Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito. El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo (compra de fierro y electrodos). Por su analisis y evaluación de flujo de fondos, Roger está en condiciones de pagar este primer préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of iron and electrodes for his welding and metal window bar business.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela is a shopkeeper selling soft drinks and groceries (such as rice, sugar, sweets, bread, etc.). She does not have sufficient capital since she is a single woman without a husband, therefore she needs a loan in order to buy merchandise and generate more income.

Her home is in the Irpavi II district of La Paz. She lives in a rental. This is the first time she has requested a loan from Impro. Her work and self-improvement give her the opportunity of this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Graciela es comerciante y vende refrescos y abarrotes (productos como arroz, azucar, dulces,pan, etc); no cuenta con suficiente capital ya que es persona sola y no tiene esposo, por lo cual requiere el crédito con el objetivo de comprar mercadería y generar mas ingresos. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz. Vive en alquiler Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, Su trabajo y las ganas de superación le permiten acceder a este crédito.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for her grocery store (soft drinks, sweets, rice, bread, sugar, etc.)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Adelio Alejandro

texts.es:
Adelio is a hard-working father who is dedicated to farming, an activity in which he has been involved since childhood and trained by his parents in all its aspects. As a result, today, Adelio is able to feed his wife and son. Despite exhausting and laborious nature of the work, farming has been profitable for Adelio and he is recognised by his fellow farmers as one of the most hard-working and dedicated amongst them.

To move forward, Adelio needs to buy fertiliser for his farmland and relies on you to provide him with the ability to do so.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Adelio es un padre muy empeñoso y entregado a su trabajo de agricultor, actividad que realizó desde muy niño y de cuyos padres aprendió todos los gajes de este oficio. Gracias a ello, hoy Adelio puede alimentar a su esposa e hijo. A pesar de lo cansado y laborioso, el trabajo en el campo es rentable y le ha traído a Don Adelio el reconocimiento de ser uno de los hombres más trabajadores y dedicados en el cultivo. Para seguir adelante, Adelio necesita adquirir abonos y fertilizantes para sus terrenos, y recurre a ustedes para poder lograrlo.

loans.use: Purchase of fertiliser for cultivation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional groceries

loans.name: Placida

texts.es:
Placida creates "pollera" skirts worn by "cholitas" (indigenous women who wear the traditional costume), working in a variety of fabrics. She is separated and has six children who are grown and independent. She still has one daughter dependent on her. She is the sole provider of income for her family since she cannot count on any other help.

Her home is in the Irpavi II district of La Paz. This is the first time she has requested a loan from Impro. The loan will be used to purchase fabric, lining, thread and other supplies in order to continue her work and ensure the income so necessary for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Placida elabora polleras para cholita y realiza su trabajo en diferentes tipos de tela; ella es separada y tiene seis hijos que son mayores de edad e independientes, solo una esta a su cargo. Es la única que genera ingresos para la subsistencia de su familia ya que no cuenta con otra ayuda. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz.. Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro; el crédito será destinado para realizar para la compra de tela, forro, hilos y otros, de esta manera continuar su trabajo y asegurar sus ingresos tan necesarios para mantener a su familia..

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, lining, thread and other supplies to make traditional skirts

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
Marina makes living selling small audio visual equipments such as MP3 and MP4 players and others. She lives in the Alto la Florida zone of the city of La Paz. She rents her residence since she does not own a home.

This is her first loan request at IMPRO.

She will use the loan to purchase inventory (MP3, MP4, flash memory and others). She is a fighter, being a single mother with a small daughter starting kindergarten. In IMPRO, we feel that she deserves this opportunity.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Marina se dedica a la venta de equipos pequeños audio visuales como ser MP3, MP4 y otros.

Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona Alto la florida de la de la ciudad de La Paz. Vive en alquiler ya que no cuenta con una vivienda propia.

Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro.

El crédito será destinado para la compra de mercadería (MP3, MP4,FLASH MEMORI Y OTROS) Es una persona luchadora ya que es madre soltera y su pequeña hija esta en el nivel inicial de Kinder. En IMPRO creemos que se merece esta oportunidad.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise such as MP3, MP4, flash memory and other small electronics for resale.

loans.name: Maribel Beatriz

texts.es:
Maribel is a woman dedicated to her work as a farmer. She grows potatoes, maize, and other seasonal products. The income from farming pays for the education of her son who lives in the city of Lima, where Maribel has sent him to benefit from its higher standard of education. As a result, Maribel has to make sacrifices in order to send money to her son, for which she is recognised as a hard-working and dedicated mother in her community.

Maribel needs to improve her farm’s crop yield but is unable to do so because of lack of capital. She hopes she can count on you.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Maribel, es una mujer muy entregada a su labor como agricultora, ella produce papa, maíz y otros diversos productos que cultiva por temporadas. Gracias a esta actividad puede solventar los gastos de su hijo quien vive en la ciudad de Lima, donde Maribel lo envió para que logre una mejor preparación académica. Para esto, ella tiene que sacrificarse en sus chacras y lograr enviar la pensión de su hijo, y estos son los reconocimientos de doña Maribel en su comunidad, ser una madre abnegada y trabajadora. Ella necesita ahora mejorar sus cultivos con los insumos adecuados, pero no puede comprarlos porque esta pasando aprietos económicos, confía en poder contar con ustedes.

loans.use: Purchase of agricultural products to increase crop yield

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena M. sells tins of tomatoes, oil, and rice at the seashore. She is married, but her husband's income from carpentry is not sufficient for Philomena and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for  additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: As additional capital to expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ulises Amilcar

texts.es:
Ulises is a hard working man dedicated to agriculture. He wishes to increase the output of his fields and therefore improve the income for his home, especially for the education of his children who are still school age and need many school supplies. This is especially true of his oldest daughter, who had to move away from her parents to get a better quality education and is currently living in a neighboring city at the home of a relative. Without a doubt, Mr. Sivestre wants to increase his income to be able to cover all these expenses. For this reason he needs to buy new seeds and fertilizer for his fields.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Ulises es un hombre trabajador y dedicado a la agricultura, él desea poder incrementar la producción de sus terrenos y así mejorar los ingresos para su hogar, en especial para la educación de sus hijos, quienes son aún escolares y requieren de mayor cantidad de útiles, sobre todo, su hija mayor, que tuvo que alejarse de sus padres para procurar una mejor calidad de educación y está ahora en una ciudad vecina en casa de un pariente de la familia. Pero sin duda, don Ulises requiere incrementar sus ingresos para tener la posibilidad de solventar todos estos gastos. Para esto debe comprar nuevas semillas y abonos necesarios para sus tierras.

loans.use: Acquire supplies for his farm.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a forty-eight-year-old widow with six children. She lost her husband eight years ago in a car accident. As a single parent, the total responsibility of the children rests upon her shoulders. Through hard work, she has been able to support three children to finish school. 

For the past twenty years, Comfort has been trading in palm oil, vegetable oil and salt. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk gallons of vegetable oil, palm oil and salt to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children’s educational fees. She belongs to the community group called El-shadai Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to repay the loan. Comfort is in the photograph taken at her business site.

loans.use: To buy bulk gallons of vegetable oil, palm oil and salt.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is thirty-four years old. She is married with three children who are currently in school. She is a petty trader who trades in dry pepper, salt, and onion in the local market. She wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of dry pepper, salt and assorted spices to serve her customers. She believes this will help her to raise more income for her family. She hopes to use part of her proceeds to finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called El-shadai Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of dry pepper, salt and assorted spices.

loans.name: Silvestre

texts.es:
Sivestre is a farmer, not only devoted to his work but also to being the father of a family. He works hard in his fields of crops and in the raising of animals, which he takes out to graze in the early mornings. Without a doubt it is not an easy task, but the love for his family gives his work reason and meaning. Currently, Silvestre wants to improve his situation by increasing the number of animals which in the long run will provide better financial income. For starters he would like to buy a sheep of good breeding. If you support him, he will be forever grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Silvestre es un padre agricultor, no tan sólo comprometido con su trabajo sino también con su rol de padre de familia. Trabaja duramente en sus terrenos de cultivos y en la crianza de animales, los cuales desde tempranas horas del día, lleva a pastear a los alrededores de sus terrenos. Sin duda, no es una tarea fácil, pero el amor por los suyos es lo que le da un fin y un sentido a todo. Pero ahora, Silvestre quiere mejorar, incrementando la cantidad de animales, los que con el transcurso del tiempo le darán mejores ingresos económicos. Para empezar, desea comprar una oveja de buena raza. Si usted lo apoya, estará agradecido de por vida.

loans.use: Acquire new animals for his livestock business

loans.name: Laneh Kuru Group

texts.en:
This group is called Laneh Kuru (Believe in God in Temne). Its members are Aminata B., the group leader, who sells clothes and shoes and Sallamatu K., who sells second-hand clothes. They want a loan of Le 2,000,000.00.

This group has experienced the benefit of getting a loan because through a previous loan from SMT their businesses have kept on growing. Having now repaid their last loan, they are asking for a new loan from Kiva to help them further expand their businesses.

Aminata is 49 years old. She was born in Lunsar, about 50 miles west of Makeni. She is currently residing in Makeni where she trades in clothes together with her five chilren. Her husband remains in Lunsar, where he farms together with his other wives.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, shoes, and second-hand clothes to expand his business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
Angela sells food (she makes dishes and sells them in the street for reasonable prices), she has 4 children, and she is the only one who generates income in her family since her husband lost his job not too long ago and has no savings. She and her family live in Irpavi II (in the city of La Paz), but their rent is rather expensive given Angela's income.

This is her first credit with Impro. The amount will go towards purchasing supplies wholesale (rice, noodles, potatoes, meat, and vegetables), which will allow her to reduce her costs considerably and therefore improve her quality of life. Since she is a fighter, she hopes to help her children get ahead. She qualified favorably in our evaluation, which is why it is possible for her to receive this credit.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Angela es vendedora de comida (cocina platos y los vende en la calle por módicos precios), tiene 4 hijos y es la única que genera ingresos en su familia puesto que no hace mucho perdió a su esposo y no tiene nada ahorrado. Ella y su familia viven en la zona de Irpavi II (ciudad de La Paz) pero pagan un alquiler bastante caro, dados los ingresos de Angela.

Este es su primer crédito en Impro, el monto será destinado para la compra de insumos (arroz, fideo, papa, carne y verdura en general) al por mayor, lo que le permitira reducir sus costos considerablemente y por lo tanto, mejorar su calidad de vida. Puesto que es una mujer luchadora, desea sacar a sus hijos adelante y calificó favorablemente en nuestra evaluación, esta en posibilidades de recibir el crédito.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Oscar Vladimir

texts.es:
Oscar is a young entrepreneur working (in a law firm and an internet cafe) and studying law at the public university. He lives with his parents, helping with food, water and light expenses. Oscar and his family live in Sopocachi Bajo, a hillside in one of the poorest areas of the city.

This is his first loan through Impro. The loan will be used to purchase a computer for education--he adds that he has never had one. The completed analysis allows us to approve this client's request.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer.

Oscar es un joven emprendedor que trabaja (en un bufete de abogados y en café Internet) y estudia (va a la universidad pública, esta en la carrera de Derecho), vive con sus padres, los cuales reciben su ayuda económica en gastos de alimentación y pagos de agua y luz. Oscar y su familia viven en Sopocachi Bajo, ladera sur (una de las zonas más pobres de la ciudad).

Este es su primer crédito en Impro, el préstamo será usado para la compra de una computadora (el propósito es educacional, a esto se añade que nunca ha tenido una). El análisis realizado nos permite aprobar la solicitud de este cliente.

loans.use:
Education (purchase of a computer)
EDUCACIÓN (COMPRA DE COMPUTADORA)

loans.name: Adilia

texts.es:
Mrs. Adilia Reátegui Portocarrero is a very cheerful and enthusiastic 49 year old woman. She is a member of Santo Cristo De Bagazan Community Bank and lives in the San Matin region, Rioja district. With her characteristic unassuming manner, she helps the community that has provided her with the opportunity to progress.

Adilia prepares and sells food dishes from an air-conditioned part of her house. Students from the nearby technical college are her most frequent customers. She decided to start her restaurant business after several years of working in the catering industry. It is something she enjoys and also allows her to share her time between running her business and taking care of household chores without much difficulty.

With this loan, repayable over six months, she plans to buy sugar, bananas, and oil in bulk to reduce her costs. She also plans to sell soft drinks as requested by her customers.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Adilia Reátegui Portocarrero es socia del Banco Comunal “SANTO CRISTO DE BAGAZAN”, vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Rioja y distrito de Rioja se dedica a la preparación y venta de comida, en un ambiente acondicionado en su propia casa, ubicada en el Jr: Angaisa Nº 115 donde diariamente acuden los estudiantes del tecnológico quienes son sus comensales mas frecuentes ya que ella vive cerca de esta institución . Decidió iniciar su negocio de preparación de comida tipo menú ya que es una actividad a la que ella se dedica por varios años y le gusta , lo que le permite compartir su tiempo entre el negocio y las tareas domesticas sin mayores dificultades. Con el préstamo de S/. 2000.00 a cual será pagados en 6 meses, implementará su negocio comprando arroz, azúcar por sacos, plátano en racimos y aceite a granel ya que sus costos cada vez son más elevados , además esta implementando su negocio con la venta de bebidas gasificadas ya que sus comensales lo requerían. La señora Adilia tiene 49 años, es una muy mujer entusiasta, alegre y con la humildad que lo caracteriza contribuye al progreso de la comunidad que le dio la oportunidad de salir adelante.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.es:
Mrs Carmen Rosa P. M. is a member of Maria Garcia Community Bank. She lives in San Martin region, Moyobamba province and district with her mother and children. Carmen works tirelessly so that she can lead a productive and fruitful life and looks forward to a future full of possibilities.

Carmen is a teacher by profession. However, being unable to find work and with support from her husband and a loan she received, she decided to start a handicraft business from home. With this loan, repayable over six months, Carmen plans to buy fabrics with different finishes, threads, ribbons of different colours, sequins, and sewing needles of different sizes, so that she can give her customers the kind of attention to detail that they deserve.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Carmen Rosa P.
