Los préstamos que ha recibido le han servido para pagar por adelantado los cosméticos que ofrece y así, tener un stock de productos.

A ella le gustaría tener una tienda donde pueda vender variedad de productos.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Gianina

texts.es:
Gianina is a teacher, but she has also been dedicated for 4 years to offering products for sale. Depending on the season, she sells clothes, shoes and other products. Her neighbors and friends of the school where she works order the products from her. She also sells cosmetics from a catalog.

The loans that she has requested have served to pay for the products that they order from her.

She would like to have a shore where she could offer clothes and beauty products. In the future, she would like to open a spa.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Gianina es profesora, pero también se dedica a hacer pedidos de productos desde hace 4 años. Dependiendo de la temporada, ella vende ropa, zapatos y otros productos. Sus vecinos y amistades del colegio donde trabaja le hacen los pedidos. Ella también vende cosméticos por catálogo.

Los préstamos que ha solicitado los ha utilizado para pagar los productos que le piden.

A ella le gustaría tener una tienda donde ofrecer ropa y productos de belleza. En un futuro, quisiera abrir un spa.

loans.use: To pay in advance for the products that she offers, such as clothes, shoes and beauty products.

loans.name: Betti Dori

texts.es:
Betti is a determined woman and constant in what she does. Her great courage and effort has been worthwhile, because more than 18 years ago she undertook to open her own business alone: her convenience store. Her motivation was her son; to give him all that he needed. Today her son is an honest man and his only support always was Betti. Upon fulfilling the noble task of being both father and mother for him, he has now finished his university studies. Betti needs a loan to be able to increase the merchandise of her convenience store and to buy new showcases and shelves for the exhibition of her products.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Betti es una mujer luchadora y constante en lo que hace, su gran valor y esfuerzo le ha valido para que por más de 18 años emprenda ella sola su propio negocio, su bodega. Su motivación fue su hijo, darle todo lo necesario. Hoy su hijo ya es un hombre de bien y su único sostén siempre fue Betti que al cumplir la noble tarea de ser padre y madre para él, ahora, él debe terminar sus estudios universitarios. Betti necesita un préstamo para poder incrementar la mercadería de su bodega y comprar nuevas vitrinas y estantes para la exhibición de sus productos.

loans.use: To acquire new merchandise for her wine cellar as well as new showcases and shelves.

loans.name: Roci

texts.es:
Roci worked in a clothes hanger factory, where she learned to make them. The procedure is not complex, since it is all done by hand. It was thus that, since 1 year ago, she decided to become independent and put her own workshop in her house. Her husband helps to contact clients and to distribute the hangers.

The loans that she has received served for the purchase of the materials that she needs to manufacture the hangers.

Roci wants her business to grow and to move the workshop to another place.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Roci trabajaba en una fábrica de ganchos colgadores de ropa, por lo que aprendió a hacerlos. El procedimiento no es complejo, ya que todo se hace a mano. Fue así, que desde hace 1 año decidió independizarse y puso su propio taller en su casa. Su esposo le ayuda a contactar los clientes y a repartir los ganchos.

Los préstamos que ha recibido le han servido para la compra de los materiales que necesita para fabricar los ganchos.

Roci quiere que su negocio crezca y poner el taller en otro lugar.

loans.use: To buy materials to make clothes hangers.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa has been dedicated to the sale of cosmetics from a catalog for 10 years. Her neighbors know that she sells beauty products, so they always go to her to buy them. She has also sold clothes to order for 3 years.

In addition, Rosa has worked doing maintenance in a doctor's office for 4 years.

The loan that she has requested will serve to pay the debts that she has and to have a stock of cosmetic products in her house.

Rosa would like to fix up a large patio outside her house to serve as a store-bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catálogo desde hace 10 años. Sus vecinos saben que ella vende productos belleza, por lo que siempre la buscan para comprarle. También, vende ropa por pedidos desde hace 3 años.

Asimismo, Rosa trabaja haciendo mantenimiento en un consultorio desde hace 4 años.

Los préstamos que ha pedido le han servido para pagar las deudas que tenía, y para tener un stock de productos cosméticos en su casa.

Rosa quisiera arreglar el amplio patio exterior de su casa y poner una tienda-bazar.

loans.use: To buy a stock of cosmetics for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lesa

texts.en: Lesa O., 32, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the Taro, taamu and bananas business. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. Lesa expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Lesa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase chemicals and pesticides as well as for home improvements by buying cements, timbers and iron roofs.

loans.use: Lesa would like to purchase chemicals and pesticides for her taro and banana business.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
Rosario learned to make earrings and necklaces by hand when she worked in a costume jewelry workshop. Then she decided to become independent and to begin her own business making earrings and necklaces. Already she has worked for 2 years in this activity.

She makes around 100 pairs of earrings per week. She distributes them to the stores of the center of Lima.

The loans have served to buy the materials that she needs to make the earrings.

She would like to be able to export her products.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosario aprendió a hacer aretes y collares a mano a raíz que trabajaba en un taller de bisutería. Luego, decidió independizarse y comenzar su propio negocio de aretes y collares. Ya tiene 2 años en esta actividad.

Ella hace alrededor de 100 pares de aretes a la semana. Los reparte en las tiendas del centro de Lima.

Los préstamos le han servido para comprar los materiales que necesita para hacer los aretes.

A ella le gustaría poder exportar sus productos.

loans.use: To buy materials for making earrings and necklaces.

loans.name: Rosa Esther

texts.es:
Rosa is a hard-working woman who is dedicated to her family and job. She has two young children who feed her desires to overcome obstacles. Rosa is a nurse and as of several years ago, she has also sold shoes and other clothing accessories. She sells her products personally to her neighbors and close friends. Her goal is to be able to buy or rent a space where she can sell her shoes with more stability, but at the moment she cannot afford this expense. In the meantime, she needs to purchase new merchandise in order to fill her orders and expand her client list. With your help, this noble nurse will soon have her own shoe store.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Rosa es una mujer de mucha dedicación al trabajo y a su familia, tiene dos pequeños hijos, ellos son los que alimentan sus deseos de superación. Rosa es enfermera y desde varios años atrás también se dedica a vender zapatos y otros accesorios de vestir. Ella ofrece sus productos de manera personal a sus vecinos y amigos cercanos. Su meta es poder comprar o alquilar un local donde pueda vender sus zapatos con mayor estabilidad, pero ahora no puede solventar ese gasto. Por lo pronto necesita comprar nueva y novedosa mercadería para satisfacer sus pedidos y ampliar la lista de sus clientes. Con tu ayuda, esta noble enfermera tendrá pronto su propia zapatería.

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise in order to obtain a larger number of clients

loans.name: Dolores

texts.es:
Dolores has been dedicated to the sale of shoes by order for 3 years. A neighbor manufactures the shoes. She buys them from him and offers them to her friends and acquaintances from her daughter’s school. She also works cleaning houses.

The loans have served to pay for the shoes that she offers and to cover family expenses.

She would like to sell the shoes in a position in the market.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Dolores se dedica a la venta de zapatos por pedido desde hace 3 años. Un vecino fabrica los zapatos, por lo que ella le compra y los ofrece a sus amistades y conocidos del colegio de su hija. Ella también se dedica a hacer trabajos de limpieza en casas.

Los préstamos le han servido para pagar los zapatos que ofrece y para cubrir gastos familiares.

A ella le gustaría vender los zapatos en un puesto en el mercado.

loans.use: To buy shoes for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Paola

texts.es:
Paola is a cashier in a discotheque, but she has also been dedicated to the sale of clothes for 4 years. Her clients are her neighbors and fellow workers. Paola has a stock of clothes kept in the house of her aunt, who helps her with the sales. She has been growing her stock little by little. Now she has more varieties than before.

The loans have served to buy the clothes wholesale.

Paola would like to sell the clothes in a position in the market.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Paola es cajera en una discoteca, pero también se dedica a la venta de ropa por pedidos desde hace 4 años. Sus clientes son sus vecinas y compañeros de trabajo. Paola tiene un stock de ropa guardado en la casa de su tía, quien le ayuda en las ventas. Ella ha ido aumentando su stock poco a poco. Ahora tiene más variedades que antes.

Los préstamos le han servido para comprar la ropa por mayor.

Paola quisiera vender la ropa en un puesto en el mercado.

loans.use: To buy clothes wholesale for resale.

loans.name: Sofía

texts.es:
Sofía has sold cosmetics by catalogue for 1 year. Before she sold handbags that her father-in-law manufactured, but the business was no longer profitable, so she decided to change her area of sales.

Sofía is also a cashier in a record store, and her clients are her coworkers.

The loans that she has received served to purchase a stock of cosmetics to have in her house so that she can offer them quickly.

She would like to offer her products from a store-bazaar in her house, along with her mother. In addition, she would like to have a position in the market.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Sofía vende cosméticos por catálogo desde hace 1 año. Antes vendía las carteras que su suegro fabricaba, pero el negocio ya no rendía económicamente, por lo que decidió cambiar de rubro de ventas.

Sofía también es cajera en una discoteca, por lo que sus clientes son sus compañeros de trabajo.

Los préstamos que ha recibido le han servido para tener un stock de cosméticos en su casa y así ofrecerlos rápidamente.

A ella le gustaría tener junto con su mamá una tienda-bazar en su casa y ofrecer sus productos. Además, quisiera tener un puesto en el mercado.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of cosmetics to have for sale in her house.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana has be dedicated to the sale of ceramic jars and vases for 3 years. She sells her products in the market near her home. Previously she sold cosmetics by catalog, but she was offered the ceramics business and she had no doubts about entering this business.

The loans that she has received have served to purchase ceramics wholesale.

She would like to have a store where she could offer toys and decorative items.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Ana se dedica a la venta de jarras y vasos de cerámica desde hace 3 años. Ella vende sus productos en el mercado cerca de su casa. Antes vendía cosméticos por catálogo, pero le ofrecieron la venta de cerámica y no dudo en incursionar en este negocio.

Los préstamos que ha recibido le han servido para comprar la cerámica por mayor.

A ella le gustaría tener una tienda donde ofrecer juguetes y adornos.

loans.use: To buy ceramics wholesale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.es:
Gabriela has been dedicated to the sale of sandwiches for 6 years. Every night she sets up her tables and chairs outside of her house and begins to sell until midnight. It was her sister who transferred the business to her, since Gabriela previously had a convenience store, but she had to close it due to problems.

In addition, Gabriela has sold clothes to order to her acquaintances for 2 years. Her husband, who is in the northern part of the country, offers clothes for sale in that zone.

The loans that she has requested served to buy wholesale the ingredients that she needs to make the sandwiches.

She would like to have her own house and to setup a soda fountain.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Gabriela se dedica a la venta de sánguches desde hace 6 años. Todas las noches saca sus mesas y sillas afuera de su casa y empieza a vender hasta la medianoche. Fue su hermana quien le traspasó el negocio, ya que antes Gabriela tenía una bodega, pero por problemas, tuvo que cerrarla.

Además, Gabriela vende ropa por pedidos a sus conocidos desde hace 2 años. Su esposo, quien es del norte del país, le ofrece la ropa por esa zona.

Los préstamos que ha solicitado le han servido para comprar por mayor los ingredientes que necesita para hacer los sánguches.

A ella le gustaría tener su casa propia y poner una fuente de soda.

loans.use: To buy wholesale the ingredients to make sandwiches.

loans.name: Elena Viviana

texts.es:
Elena is a mother and she's always alert to what has to be done to guarantee that her kids have what they need. Three years ago, she was presented with a chance to start a business selling food products: trout and fish, among other products. She travels out to mines to sell her products and to see her husband who works in the same area, too. At home, she also earns money making fruit yogurt which she stores in her lone freezer. She sells the yogurt in nearby markets and on the street to passers-by. She would like to be able to buy larger freezers and become a great yogurt entrepeneur. Step by step, Elena will reach her goal and she's starting with this request for a loan. Let's help Elena become a great entrepeneur.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Elena es una madre de familia que siempre está velando por la seguridad económica de sus hijos. Hace tres años se le presentó la oportunidad de incursionar en el mundo de la venta de productos alimenticios como la trucha, queso, entre otros. Ella viaja a los asientos mineros y ofrece estos productos personalmente, de esta manera también visita a su esposo, que trabaja en un lugar cercano. En su casa también se dedica a la elaboración de yogurt frutado que guarda en su propia refrigeradora, luego sale a los mercados cercanos y los vende de manera ambulatoria. A ella le gustaría poder comprar congeladoras más grandes y convertirse en una gran empresaria del yogurt, paso a paso Elena conseguirá su meta, y para comenzar solicita este préstamo. Ayudemos a Elena a convertirse en una gran empresaria.

loans.use: Buy freezer for food business.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María’s husband is a carpenter and has a small furniture factory beside their house. He relies on various operators and industrial machines. María helps him with the logistics of the business. She also receives calls from the clients, that are large businesses that order furniture.

María has been dedicated to business all her life. She began by selling cebiche (a native seafood dish) in the market. Later she opened a poultry shop, but she had to close it for family reasons. Then she had a restaurant and a convenience store. She has also sold cosmetics by catalog.

Nevertheless, since she was married María has helped her husband in the administration of the furniture factory. They have been married already 17 years.

Currently, María also works in an office of a property development company.

The loans have served to support her husband in the purchase of materials for making furniture.

She would like her husband’s business to be a success. For this, it needs more labor and to improve the infrastructure of the small factory.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

El esposo de María es carpintero y tiene una pequeña fábrica de muebles al costado de su casa. Cuenta con varios operarios y máquinas industriales. María le ayuda en la logística del negocio. También recepciona las llamadas de los clientes, que son empresas grandes que le mandan a hacer muebles.

María toda su vida se ha dedicado a los negocios. Ella comenzó vendiendo cebiche en el mercado. Después puso una pollería, pero tuvo que cerrarlo por motivos familiares. Luego ha tenido un restaurante y una bodega. También ha vendido cosméticos por catálogo.

Sin embargo, María desde que está casada ha ayudado a su esposo en la administración de la fábrica de muebles. Ya han pasado 17 años desde que se casó.

En la actualidad, María también trabaja en una oficina como promotora.

Los préstamos le han servido para apoyar a su esposo en la compra de materiales para elaborar los muebles.

A ella le gustaría que el negocio de esposo sea una empresa. Para esto, necesita más mano de obra y mejorar la infraestructura de la pequeña fábrica.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make furniture.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa has been a seamstress for 8 years, she learned to seam whilst working on a textiles factory.

Before, she had a workshop inside her home but six months ago she decided to open her own workshop at the local market.

She has several sewing machines and for the moment she works by herself at the workshop, where she works all day long. She has used the loans she has received so far to refurbish her workshop.

Teresa would like her business to grow more and to be better known.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Teresa se dedica a la costura desde hace 8 años. Teresa aprendió a coser debido a que trabajaba en una fábrica textil. Ella antes tenía su taller en su casa, pero hace 6 meses decidió poner su taller en el mercado de su barrio. Tiene varias máquinas de costura industriales. Por el momento, ella trabaja sola en el taller. Atiende todo el día. Los préstamos los ha utilizado para refaccionar el local propio que ahora tiene en el mercado.

Teresa quisiera que su negocio crezca más y hacerse más conocida.

loans.use: To refurbish the sewing workshop she has at the local market

loans.name: Volga Agripina

texts.es:
Agripina works with steadiness and determination at whatever she does, using every minute to improve her economic situation. That's why she decided, after studying to be a pharmacist, to set up on her own and open a shop on a main street of the city where she lives. Her sales are improving every day, driving her plan to expand her shop even more. She's asking for a 2300-soles loan so that she can add to the merchandise she sells. Help Agripina continue to grow in her profession.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Agripina es una mujer luchadora y constante en lo que hace, ella aprovecha cada momento de su vida para poder mejorar su situación económica. Así que ella después de estudiar la carrera de farmacia ha decidió ejercerla de manera independiente abriendo así una botica en una calle céntrica de su localidad. Cada día sus ventas van mejorando, por lo que su deseo es implementar aún más su botica, para ello solicita un préstamo de 2300 soles para que de esa manera pueda tener mayor cantidad de fármacos a vender. Apoya a Agripina a seguir desenvolviéndose en su carrera.

loans.use: Buy products to set up a drugstore.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
For some years, Ana has operated a shop selling everyday commodities. Despite some hard times when the business seemed to be failing, Ana's perseverance kept it going and she's now firmly established, operating the business from her house. Her hope is to continue improving the business so that she can increase her income and guarantee that her young children have what they need. For this, she needs to increase her working capital and buy wholesale supplies of merchandise. Your support for Ana's loan will be very important to the development of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Ana desde hace varios años que se ha dedicado al comercio de productos de primera necesidad. A pesar de los momentos difíciles que ha pasado cuando el negocio parecía fracasar, la constancia de Ana le permitieron crecer y hoy ha establecido su bodega en su propia casa, donde ella puede comercializar estos productos. Su deseo es seguir mejorando para que así pueda obtener mayores recursos económicos, de esa manera garantizar un ingreso para sus dos pequeños hijos. Por ello necesita incrementar su capital y comprar más productos al por mayor. Tu apoyo en el préstamo de Ana será de mucha importancia para su desarrollo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Liz Tania

texts.es:
Liz is a very dedicated mother of two. She takes care of her children, who are her reason for living. In order to provide for them, she has decided to independently practice as a cosmetologist. She has set-up a small beauty parlor inside her home and she offers her services to her neighbors.

Liz requests a loan of 1500 soles that she will invest buying necessary material and a machine to cut hair. Support Liz to continue with this great project.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Liz es una madre de familia muy dedicada al cuidado de sus dos pequeños hijos, quienes son su razón de vivir, por el cuidado que tiene que brindarles ha decidido ejercer de manera independiente su oficio de cosmetóloga en su propia casa. Para esto, ha implementado su propio salón de belleza en un pequeño espacio de su casa donde ofrece su servicio para los vecinos de su localidad.

Liz solicita un préstamo de 1500 soles que invertirá en la compra de materiales necesarios y una máquina cortadora de cabello. Apoya a Liz a continuar adelante con este gran proyecto.

loans.use: To buy beauty products and a machine to cut hair

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
First loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=33827&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Rosalinda is a partner of the village bank “Shared Swallow”.

Rosalinda is 33, married and has 2 children. Rosalinda and her husband have a restaurant called “Cincomentarios” in a rented venue located in a central street in the city of Ayacucho and in front of an inter-city bus station. The restaurant serves all day long.

Rosalinda needs a loan of 1000 soles which she would invest in buying rice, sugar, vegetables and meat.

Rosalinda’s dream is to expand her business, have her own locale and provide her children with a good education.

loans.use: Rosalinda needs a loan of 1000 soles which she would invest in buying rice, sugar, vegetables and meat.

loans.name: Janet Jackeline

texts.es:
Janet is father and mother to her three children. Driven by her great hope to earn her own income, she set up a small shop, selling basic commodities, two years ago. Thanks to her efforts and dedication, she has seen her business improve day after day. Janet feels in her bones the effects of the increase in the cost of living in her country and she dreams of having a mini-market, selling all kinds of products that are both of good quality and low price, where all her neighbors can come. For her shop to keep growing, she needs to buy more products, so she's asking for your help and trust.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Janet es padre y madre para sus tres hijos, movida por sus grandes deseos de generar ingresos propios, puso una tienda de productos de primera necesidad hace dos años. Ella ha visto como ha mejorado su negocio día tras día con su esfuerzo y dedicación. Janet sueña con tener un minimarket, al cual acudan todos los vecinos de su localidad, vender toda clase de productos de muy buena calidad y a precios bajos, ya que ella sufre en carne propia el aumento del costo de vida en su país. Para que su bodega crezca día a día, necesita comprar más productos, y es para lo que ella ahora pide su apoyo y confianza.

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
Luz and her family work day and night at the chores required of people who farm and raise livestock, chores that she's been doing for 12 years. She has two children and her hard work is for them. Farming chores are difficult and tiring because they require working the soil in the hot sun and tending to the needs of farm animals. All this work for a woman on her own is exhausting but Luz has to do it because it is how she supports herself and her children. In order to improve her crop production, she needs to buy seeds, fertilizer and other things. Feed for the animals that she's raising, for example. Put your trust in her work and give her your support.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Luz, una madre de familia que trabaja constantemente en las tareas de agricultura y ganadería, labor a la cual se viene dedicando 12 años de su vida. Ella tiene dos hijos y ellos son el motivo de su esfuerzo diario. Las tareas del campo son arduas y muy cansadas ya que tiene que labrar la tierra bajo en sol extenuante y por otro lado sacar a pastear su ganado. Todas estas labores para una mujer sola son agotadoras, pero Luz debe hacerlas porque de ello depende el sustento de su casa. Para mejorar la producción de sus cultivos ella necesita comprar más semillas, abonos y demás. Además de la alimentación para los animales que ella cría. Confía en su trabajo y bríndale tu apoyo.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer to improve quality of farm crop.

loans.name: Elena Gladys

texts.es:
Elena is a mother with a desire to succeed. For this reason, she is devoted to pig raising on a small farm that she has established in a relative's home. In this way, she is able to generate more income and satisfy her family's and her home's needs. Elena hopes to have a larger farm in the future, which will provide improved quality for her business. For this, she needs to purchase more pigs. In order that they grow better and so their meat is more profitable, she needs to feed them balanced meals. For this, Elena is requesting your help. In this way, she may also improve parts of her farm.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Elena es una madre de familia con muchos deseos de superación, por esta razón se dedica a la crianza de cerdos en una pequeña granja que ha implementado en la casa de un familiar. De esta forma puede generar más ingresos y satisfacer las necesidades de su familia y hogar. Elena desea en un futuro tener una granja más grande, la cual le permita mejorar la calidad de su negocio. Para ello necesita comprar más cerdos, para que estos crezcan mejor, y que su carne sea más rentable, se les debe alimentar con comida balanceada, y es para ellos que Elena pide su apoyo, y junto a ello podrá también mejorar en algo el aspecto de su granja.

loans.use: To improve the quality of her pigs by purchasing balanced food and to improve her farm.

loans.name: Ines Carmen

texts.es:
Ines is a mother who is very engaged in the care of her children. So that she could work without neglecting her children, Ines devoted herself to selling various products such as clothing, home furnishings, ceramics, etc. She would like to have her own shop where she could sell clothing and accessories. For this, she saves whatever she can every day. However, many times, expenses increase and Ines' savings have to diminish. Ines needs your help so that she can have her own store. She will continue selling her products on foot. Nevertheless, she needs to purchase more wholesale merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Inés es una madre de familia muy entregada al cuidado de sus hijos para poder trabajar sin descuidar la atención de ellos, Inés se dedica a vender todo tipo de artículos como; prendas de vestir, adornos para la casa, cerámica, etc. A ella le gustaría tener una tienda propia donde pueda vender ropa y accesorios, para eso ahorra todo lo que puede día a día, pero muchas veces el gasto en su casa se incrementa y los ahorros de Inés tienen que disminuir. Para que su proyecto de tener una tienda propia de sus primeros pasos, Inés necesita de su colaboración. Ella seguirá vendiendo sus productos de manera ambulante, pero necesita comprar al por mayor más mercadería.

loans.use: Increase her working capital and acquire new products so that she can continue her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
first loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28975&_tpos=9&_tpg=1

Alejandra D. L. C. P. is partner in the village bank “Llamkasum” (Quechua for “We work in Quechua”.)

Alejandra is 42 years old, married and has 5 children. Alejandra sells peas, beans and sweet potato from a stall at the Nery García market from dawn, all day long, every day of the week and plants potatoes and wheat in their district HuamanguilL. which she then sells in the same market.

Alejandra needs a loan of 1500 soles, which would be invested to buy peas, beans and sweet potatoes.

Alejandra’s dream is to expand her business and that her children grow up to be professionally trained.

loans.use: Buy peas, beans and sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Primitiva Aquelina

texts.es:
In her search for a new future, more than two years ago, Primitiva decided to start her own business. In her home, she established a small shop. For this, she has had to deA. with a number of sacrifices. She has dealt with, and overcome, many difficulties. As a result, her shop continues and her faithful customers motivate her to continue. Today, Primitiva longs to improve her economic situation. For this, she needs to improve her shop and stock it with school supplies. Please support Primitiva as she continues with these efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Primitiva decidió hace más D. 2 años emprender su propio negocio en busca D. un nuevo futuro. InstA.ó en su casa una pequeña tienda y por ella ha tenido que realizar una serie D. sacrificios. Ella ha pasado muchas dificultades, y ha superado todas, por eso su bodega sigue en pie y sus fieles clientes también la animan a continuar. Hoy Primitiva, tiene el anhelo D. mejorar la economía D. su casa, para ello necesita implementar mejor su tienda y a manera D. bazar surtirla con útiles escolares. Apoya a Primitiva a continuar con estos esfuerzos.

loans.use: Expand her product selectiona and acquire school supplies so she can sell them in her shop.

loans.name: Ambrosia

texts.en:
first loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=32985&_tpos=2&_tpg=1

Ambrosia belongs to the Señor de Huanca Village Bank.

She is a 42-year-old single mother and has 3 children. She sells emollient, a hot drink prepared with flax seeds and an herb with curative properties. She is a mobile seller with a cart in a central street in Ayacucho. She works at night.

Ambrosia needs a 1000 soles loan to buy sugar, herbs and linseed oil.

She wants to educate her children so that they could be professionals, but she also dreams about building a house and bettering her business.

loans.use: Buy sugar, herbs and linseed oil.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
first loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=34803&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Miriam belongs to the Magnolia Village Bank.

She lives with her husband, is 26 and has a 7-year-old daughter. She sells ladies' clothes in a store located in a busy shopping arcade in Ayacucho.

She orders her products from Lima. She also does housework and has a moto-taxi with her husband.

Miriam needs a 1000 soles loan to buy polo shirts, pants and pullovers. She would like to extend her business to supply more products, and to have her own house.

loans.use: Buy polo shirts, pants and pullovers.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.en:
First loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=31732&_tpos=2&_tpg=1

Delfina belongs to the Virgen María Village Bank.

She is divorced, is 55 and has 2 children. She sells different kinds of clothes in the Ayacucho region ferias and also in the Ayacuchan jungle. During the week, she sells clothes in the Nazarenas feria. She purchases her products in Lima.

Delfina needs a 1000 soles loan to buy cardigans.

She dreams about expanding her business, having a permanent store and having economic stability.

loans.use: Buy cardigans.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
During her life, Norma has been able to conquer many difficult circumstances and she has not been left defeated by any of them. Two years ago, she took a step forward to forge a bright future. Norma began selling wool. She also knits and creates beautiful garments. With this activity, she is sustaining her home and her three children, who give her the strength to move forward. For this she persists and she expects even more that her sales compensate for her family's daily expenses. Norma now wishes to increase her merchandise and venture into clothing sales. Please support Norma to get ahead with her projects. She promises not to betray your trust in her work.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Norma pudo durante su vida vencer muchas circunstancias difíciles y no se dejó derrotar por ninguna. Hace dos años ella dio un paso al frente para forjarse un buen futuro. Norma comenzó la venta de lanas y también ella misma teje y confecciona bellas prendas. Con esta actividad está sosteniendo su hogar y a sus tres hijos quienes le dan la fuerza de seguir adelante. Por ello persiste y se exige aún más para que sus ventas compensen el diario gasto familiar. Norma tiene el deseo ahora de incrementar su mercadería e incursionar en la venta de ropa. Apoya a Norma a seguir adelante con sus proyectos. Ella promete no defraudar la confianza que pongan en su trabajo.

loans.use: Purchase wool for her knitting and also acquire clothing in order to expand her product selection.

loans.name: Ada Nelida

texts.es:
Ada is both father and mother to her small daughter. For many years, she's been devoted to selling cosmetics for the three most famous brands in her area. She began this work after receiving a personal invitation from another cosmetics agent and now she is one of the bestselling beauty salesperson. With a desire to continue advancing in this occupation and to venture into clothing sales, she sells to both old and new customers on a daily basis. Ada's secret is her charm and responsibility: She ensures her bills are paid and her customers are happy. This confidence allows Ada to offer products on credit. She wishes to expand her beauty product selection and, at the same time, purchase clothing in order to expland her business' reach. As Ada trusts her customers, she hopes that you can trust in her fighting and grateful spirit.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Ada es padre y madre para su pequeña hija, y hace varios años que se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de las tres líneas más famosas en su localidad. Ella comenzó mediante una invitación personal de otra agente de cosméticos y ahora ella es una de las más grandes vendedoras de estos productos de belleza. Con el deseo de seguir avanzando con esta ocupación e incursionar en la venta de prendas de vestir, ella ofrece diariamente a antiguos y nuevos clientes sus productos. El secreto de Ada, es su carisma y responsabilidad, por ello logra que sus pagos estén al día y que ninguno de sus clientes le falle. Esa confianza le da a Ada la capacidad de dar crédito por sus productos. Ella desea implementarse con más cosméticos y a su vez compra prendas de vestir para ampliar el rubro de su negocio. Así como Ada confía en la honradez de sus clientes, espera que ustedes confíen en su espíritu luchador y agradecido.

loans.use: Purchase new cosmetics and venture into clothing sales.

loans.name: Jhony Alfredo

texts.es:
Jhony is a young man with a desire to get ahead. Sadly, he suffered harvest losses and now he must take on odd jobs in order to improve his economic situation and overcome his misfortune. Anytime someone needs a carpenter, plumber, painter, etc. Jhony is there to fix his neighbors' problems and solve his own financial woes. In order to improve his situation and purchase tools for his work, Jhony is requesting your support and he promises to fulfill his obligation.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Jhony es un joven con muchos deseos de superación, lamentablemente sufrió pérdidas en sus cosechas y ahora le toca asumir trabajos diversos para mejorar su situación económica y superar los momentos de pérdida. Cada vez que alguna persona necesita un carpintero, un gasfitero, un pintor, etc. Jhony está allí solucionando los problemas de sus vecinos y solucionando su propio problema económico. Para reflotar su situación y comprar implementos para seguir brindando sus servicios Jhony pide un apoyo que promete no defraudar.

loans.use: An injection of capital in order to continue to provide services.

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.es:
Rebeca is a fighter who works hard every day at the difficult jobs required of farmers. She mostly grows wheat which she will soon harvest and which she nervously hopes will bring a good crop that will justify the time and effort that she's put into it. The region where Rebeca lives has been subject to significant climate changes which have caused Rebeca to lose harvests in the past. Despite being pregnant, Rebeca takes care of her land, and she's been able to count on help from relatives and friends to tend her crop, something she wasn't able to do on her own because of her condition. She now needs to buy 600 soles-worth of fertilizer. Rebeca hopes to give the child that she's expecting a better future. Please help her.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Rebeca es una mujer luchadora que cada día se empeña en las duras tareas del campo. Ella siembra principalmente trigo el cual pronto cosechará, y Rebeca espera ansiosa, una buena producción que valga el esfuerzo de tanto tiempo invertido en la tierra. En la zona donde ella vive han habido demasiados cambios climáticos y eso ha hecho que Rebeca pierda varias de sus cosechas. A pesar que ahora está embarazada cuida de su tierra, en todo este tiempo la colaboración de sus parientes y vecinos ha servido para que Rebeca saque adelante su siembra, ya que ella no podía esforzarse de la misma manera por su estado. Ahora necesita comprar sacos de abono y para ello necesita la cantidad de 600 soles, Rebeca espera darle al niño que viene en camino un mejor futuro, ayúdala.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer to improve crop yields.

loans.name: Sisi

texts.en: Sisi M., 35, is married with three children. Her husband is a fisherman supporting her and their children. She has 4 years of experience in the BBQ business. She sells to passing traffic in front of their house 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Sisi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will pay for her childrens' school fees, purchase iron roofing and a toilet seat for her bathroom.

loans.use: Sisi would like to purchase lamb chops, sausages, chicken, rice and vegetables for salad.

loans.name: Orepa

texts.en: Orepa T., 25, is married with two children.  She's the mother of two sons, her husband resides in NZ and sends money to help her support their sons. She has 4 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the passin traffic 4 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD). SPBD loans are Orepa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Orepa would like to purchasing a new canoe, torch, spear and more fishing gears.

loans.name: Siuta

texts.en: Siuta G., 42, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the BBQ/fishing business. She sells to passing traffic 5 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 800 Tala (~$333 USD). SPBD loans are Siuta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to purchase fishing gear to start up her fishing business that will be run by her husband.

loans.use: Siuta would like to purchase a bigger BBQ stove and also to buy fishing gear to start up her fishing business.

loans.name: Solia

texts.en: Solia M., 46, is married with four children. Solia M. has been in business for more than ten years now, she is one of our most successful clients, who has shown and proven the efforts in achieving her goals. She is a very hard working lady that loves to try out new business, and hates to fail.She has many years of experience in the bakery shop business. She sells to the passing traffic 3 days per week. She has 6 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1500 Tala (~$625 USD). SPBD loans are Solia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Solia would like to renovate her shower, build a small proper shelter for selling her products and also to purchase ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Eleitino

texts.en: Eleitino T., 60, is married with four children. She's the centre chief of their community of 14 ladies, with only 2 members who are inactive. Her business is going really strong, with the support of her children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 2 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Eleitino’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for her grandson's school fees.

loans.use: Eleitino would like to purchase pesticides and chemicals for her plantation.

loans.name: Pueata

texts.en: Pueata P., 40, is married with four children. She runs a plantation business and her husband is also a farmer helping her out with her business. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 2 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Pueata’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Pueata would like to purchase pesticides and chemicals for plantation.

loans.name: Melegalenuu

texts.en: Melegalenuu F., 48, is married with six children. She's the centre chief of their community of 34 women running different small businesses. Her husband is a farmer by profession supporting her business. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public 2 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Melegalenuu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Melegalenuu would like to purchase pesticides and chemicals for her plantation.

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta N., 48, is married with six children. A very energetic mother working hard to support her family, she is supporting her husband, children and as well as her husband's parents. She has many years of experience in the Plantation/ Samoan Bread business. She sells to the general public/villages 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 650 Tala (~$270 USD). SPBD loans are Elisapeta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for her son's school fees.

loans.use: Elisapeta would like to purchase pesticides and chemicals for her plantation and ingredients for her Samoan Bread business.

loans.name: Talitulia

texts.en:
Talitulia Kelemete, age 34, is married with one child. She runs a small shop in her community and also has a taro farm. Her husband helps her to operate both businesses. She has many years of experience growing and selling taro products. She sells to the general public/villages 6 days per week.

Talitulia has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Talitulia’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Talitulia would like to restock her shop and purchase chemicals for her business.

loans.name: Tiaina

texts.en:
Tiaina V., age 50, is married with 7 children. She has many years of experience in the farming business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week.

Tiaina has 1 previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD). SPBD loans are Tiaina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to renovate her house.

Tiaina has 7 children, five of whom attend the village school. Her husband is a fisherman who fishes three times a week, especially on weekends.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and chemicals for her farm

loans.name: Naotala

texts.en:
Naotala T., age 45, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in the farming business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week.

Naotala has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Naotala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

Naotala runs a taro farming business. Her business has become very succesful with the support of her husband and family. She has found a good market for exporting her taro to our neighbouring island, American Samoa.

loans.use: For maintenance of her house.

loans.name: Eseese

texts.en:
Eseese S., age 46, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in the farming business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week.

Eseese has taken 3 previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 520 Tala (~$216 USD). SPBD loans are Eseese’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

Part of her loan will be used to buy tools and chemicals for her farm, and part will pay for her children's school fees. Eseese S. is a very energetic mother who running a farming business. With support from her husband, she is able to maintain their business in good shape.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her farm

loans.name: Vinesa

texts.en:
Vinesa M., age 54, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in retail business. She sells to the general public 1 day per week. 

Vinesa has taken 7 previous loans from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD).  SPBD loans are Vinesa’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks

Vinesa is requesting her current loan to assist her in expanding her shop. She plans to buy more stock, so she can be able to have enough supply for her clients.

loans.use: To re-stock her shop and pay for her grandson's school fee

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: 26 year old Agnes A. V. is a mother of two children. Her husband is an electrician while she runs her own general store. Open four days per week, Agnes earns a weekly net cash flow of 1200 Tala (~500 USD).  SPBD loans are Agnes’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for loans from traditional banks. She is requesting a loan to purchase timber, iron roofing, nails and paint to expand her shop. She requires additional storage space because she is currently having difficulty maintaining her large amount of stock.  Agnes has a strong loan history with seven previous loans with SPBD.

loans.use: To expand general store

loans.name: Vitolia

texts.en: 43 year old Vitoria S. L. is married, with four children.  She has built four years of experience selL. BBQ foods to passerby traffic for three days a week. From this business, she earns a weekly net cash flow of 620 Tala (~258 USD).  SPBD loans are Vitoria’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for loans from traditional banks. She is requesting a loan to purchase lamb flaps, chicken, sausages, soya sauce, tomato sauce, onions and rice. She will also use part of the loan to  renovate her house and pay for her children's school fees. She has received four previous loans with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase food items for business

loans.name: Lualuai

texts.en: Lualuai N. is a 22 year old single mother with two children.  She has two years of experience as a food vendor selling to the general public four days per week.  She earns a weekly net cash flow of 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Lualuai’s only access to capital because she was has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks. She is requesting a loan to to purchase chicken, tomato sauce, flour, a new gas oven, potatoes, cooking oil and salt, as well as to purchase cement and iron roofing to renovate her small house. She has received two previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase food items for business

loans.name: Fou

texts.en: Fou P., 64, is widowed with five children. Her husband passed away three years ago. She is a very energetic mother who owns a taro plantation that is now being taken care of by her children due to her health. She has many years of experience in the Taro Plantation/Ice Cake business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Fou’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Fou would like to purchase chemicals, chain link wires for fencing, taro tops to grow, foam cups, cordial and sugar for her taro plantation.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: 62 year old Marina A. is married, with 12 children. She owns a general store which is open to the general public four days per week. She earns a weekly net cash flow of 500 Tala (~208 USD).    SPBD loans are Marina’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks.  She has received seven previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: Purchase purchase box of lamp flaps, chicken, sausages, tin fish, biscuits etc

loans.name: Tutumanu

texts.en: 43 year old Tutumanu L. is married with five children.  She has worked for many years in the taro plantation business where she sells taro to the general public. She works seven days per week and earns a weekly net cash flow of 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Tutumanu’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks. She would like to request a loan to purchase chemicals and weed killers for her taro plantation. Also, she will use part of the loan to purchase iron roofing to replace her old roof that has deteriorated. Tumanu is from a community of 12 ladies who all run the same business and support each other. She has received two previous loans with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase farming materials

loans.name: Vaalotu

texts.en: 24 year old Vaalotu T. is married with two children. She has many years of experience as a seamstress, selling her products  to the general public four days per week. She earns a weekly net cash flow of 520 Tala (~216 USD).  SPBD loans are Vaalotu’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks. She would like to request a loan in order to purchase a new industrial sewing machine to speed up her production due to increased demand. She has received six previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To expand her production

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: 35 year old Rosalina I. is married, with four children.  She has many years of experience in the banana plantation business where she sells bananas to the general public four days per week.   She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  With one previous loan from SPBD, SPBD remains Rosalina’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks. Rosalina successfully paid off her first loan and is now requesting for a second one to purchase funggicide for banana ridex, milkek C, fertilizers and weed killer. She aims to expand her business and increase her income.

loans.use: To expand banana plantation business

loans.name: Tafiau

texts.en: 28 year old Tafiau A. is married, with three children.  Tafiau is in the food vending business where she sells banana chips and ice cakes to the general public five days per week. She earns a weekly net cash flow of 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Tafiau’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for loans from traditional banks. She plans to use the loan to purchase plastic bags, cordial, sugar, bananas, salt and cooking oil. As well, she will also purchase timber and iron roofing for her house.Tafiau has received four previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To expand food vending business

loans.name: Savali

texts.en: 33 year old Savali S. is married, with five children.  She has worked in the BBQ business for many years, selling BBQ food to the general public three days per week. She earns a weekly net cash flow of 420 Tala (~175 USD).  SPBD loans are Savali’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan from traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for her children's fees and the rest will be used to purchase chicken, sausages, banana, tomato sauce, cucumbers, plates, tissues, and a gas bottle for her business. Savali has had one previous loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To improve business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase various materials for a beauty salon.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To improve her small business of selling clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase jewelry and clothing for her business.

loans.name: June

texts.en: 43 year old June A. is married, with one child. As an experienced shopkeeper, she sells to the public seven days per week , earning a weekly net cash flow of approximately 500 Tala (~208 USD). Along with her shop, June also has a plantation business to diversify her sources of income. SPBD loans are June’s only access to capital because she has not  qualified for a loan with the traditional banks. She has received five previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To re-stock and expand business

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: 21 year old Eseta P. has two years of experience working in her general store. Open to the public seven days per week, she earns a weekly net cash flow of approximately 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Eseta’s only access to capital because she has not qualified for a loan with the traditional banks. She has received three previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To re-stock and expand business

loans.name: Fofoa

texts.en: 58 years old Fofoa M. is married, with nine children.  She has many years of experience selling taro, taamu and bananas business.  Working three days per week, with assistance from her children, she earns a weekly net cash flow of approximately 420 Tala (~175 USD).  SPBD loans are Fofoa’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. She would like to request a loan to use to buy cements, timber and iron roofs to improve her home. She has received three previous loans from SPBD.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Sona

texts.fr:
This woman is an experienced dressmaker. She is seeking a loan to buy fabrics and sewing materials in order to increase her inventory of ready-to-wear clothing. This mother of ten manages to support her husband with this business. She also participates in training young girls in the techniques of making clothes.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Cette dame est une couturiére expérimentée, elle sollicite un crédit pour acheter des tissus et de la mercerie afin d'augmenter son stock de prêt à porter. Avec activité, cette mére d'uine dizaine d'enfants, arrive à soutenir son mari. Aussi elle participe à la formation des jeunes filles ux techniques de confection : coupe et couture.

loans.use: Sewing shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Cheikh Tidiane

texts.fr:
This young entrepreneur is in the business of hairstyling. Owner of a salon, he plans to use his loan to build up his equipment and improve his services. In his business, he employs three young people from Ziguinchor who thus won’t be tempted to immigrate illegally.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Ce jeune entrepreneur intervient dans le secteur de la coiffure. Propriétaire d'un salon , il compte avec ce crédit renforcer ses équipement et améliorer ses services. Par cette activité, il emploie trois (03) jeunes ziguinchorois qui ne seront pas tentés par l'immigration clandestine.

loans.use: Building up his barbershop

loans.name: Keli

texts.en:
Keli S., 51, is divorced with 3 children. She has 2 years of experience in a barbeque foods business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 460 Tala (~191 USD).

SPBD loans are Keli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She also has a vegetable and sells vegetables to supplement her barbeque business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients such as meat and vegetables.

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en:
Kalala S., 54, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience selling bananas and fruit in her business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has three previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 520 Tala (~216 USD).

SPBD loans are Kalala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her husband is a fisherman and he also helps the most in family needs.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and pesticides.

loans.name: Vauvasa

texts.en:
Vaivasa P., 57, is single with no children. She has many years of experience in sewing clothes and material. She sells to the public and villagers 6 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

SPBD loans are Vaivasa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will also use the loan for home improvement.

loans.use: To buy material and equipment for her sewing business

Selafina T., 71, is widowed with 8 children. She has many years of experience in sewing clothes and material. She sells to the public and villagers 5 days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

SPBD loans are Selafina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan money will also be used to buy cement, timber and an iron roof for home improvement. She has children overseas who always sends her money to help her out.

loans.use: Buy material and equipment for her sewing business.

SPBD loans are Leagaioalii’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband is working and helps her out with family needs.

SPBD loans are Malo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Malo will also use the money for home improvements, by buying cement, timber, and an iron roof.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and pesticides

texts.en:
Faafetai V., 37, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience selling Taro, taamu and bananas. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

SPBD loans are Faafetai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. The loan will be used also for home improvements.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en:
Telesia P., 72, is married with 7 children. She has many years of experience in selling pigs. She sells to the public and villagers 5 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 380 Tala (~158 USD).

She would like to buy cement, timber and iron for the roof. She has children who are working and living overseas and they help her out with family needs.

loans.use: To buy tools and equipment for repairing the fence for her business

Fua F., 34, is married with 5 children. She has 3 years of experience in selling bananas and taro. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

SPBD loans are Fua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also use the loan to buy cement and timber for home repairs.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Pepeu

texts.en:
Pepeu L., 65, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in the german buns and pork buns business. She sells to the local school and villagers 5 days per week. She has four previous loan(s) with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 380 Tala (~158 USD).

SPBD loans are Pepeu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan money will also be used for home repair to buy cement, timber and iron roofing. She has children who are working and help her out.

loans.use: To ingredients such as flour, yeast, drippings, and meats for the business.

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
Janice T., 34, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in the barbeque foods business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has three previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

SPBD loans are Janice’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also use the loan for home improvements by buying cement, timber, and an iron roof. Her husband is working and helps her with family needs and running the business.

loans.use: To purchase meats and ingredients needed for the bbq business

loans.name: Tauiaupolu

texts.en:
Tauiaiupolu F., 42, is married with 3 children. She has 2 years of experience in the elei and material printing business. Tauiaiupolu sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Tauiaiupolu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband is working and her two sons are very helpful in running the business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric, painting materials, brushes and elei woods for the business.

loans.name: Aniva

texts.en:
Aniva F., 33, is married with 2 children. She has many years of experience in the Samoan cocoa business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net profit to be 250 tala (approximately 104 USD).

She has one previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Aniva’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She plans to use the loan to pay for her children's school fees and to buy cement and wood for home improvements.

loans.use: Pay children's school fees and buy cement and wood for home improvements

loans.name: Salumalo

texts.en:
Salumalo V., 41, is married and has 6 children. Her husband is working and helps with the family's needs. She has many years of experience selling Samoan crafts, such as mats, earrings, hats, and tanoa (bowls). She sells to the public and villagers 6 days a week.

She is requesting a loan so she can purchase more goods to sell at the flea market, and so increase her profits. She also plans to use some of her profits to buy cement, wood, and iron roofing materials for home improvements.

Salumalo has had 5 previous loans from SPBD. SPBD loans are Salumalo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She expects her weekly net profit to be 500 Tala (about 208 USD).

loans.use: Purchase more Samoan crafts to increase sales at the flea market

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa F., 29, is married and has 3 children. For 3 years, she has had a farm growing vegetables. She sells vegetables to the villagers 3 days a week. She expects to make a profit of 250 Tala (about 104 USD) per week.

The is Luisa's first loan request. SPBD loans are Luisa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Luisa plans to use the loan to buy equipment and supplies for her business.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, barbed wire, nails, chemical, and knives

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en:
Makerita B., 44, is married and has 5 children. For 3 years, she has had a farm growing vegetables. She sells vegetables to the villagers 3 days per week. She is requesting a loan to purchase seeds, barbed wire, nails, chemicals, and other supplies for her farming needs. She expects her weekly net profit will be 200 Tala (about 83 USD).

Makerita has had 2 previous loans from SPBD. SPBD loans are Makerita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, barbed wire, nails, chemicals, and knives

loans.name: Aukusitina

texts.en:
Aukusitina P., 74, is married and has 10 children. For 3 years, she has been making and selling pancakes. She sells pancakes to the villagers 5 days per week. She is requesting a loan to purchase sacks of flour and sugar, vegetable oil, and a frying pan so she can continue making pancakes.

Aukusitina has had one previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net profit to be 250 Tala (about 104 USD). SPBD loans are Aukusitina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sack of flour, vegetable oil, sack of sugar, frying pan to make pancakes

loans.name: Toeafe

texts.en:
Toeafe Tiata, 50, is married and has 2 children. She has run a Bingo business for 3 years. She sells to the villagers 3 days per week.

Toeafe is requesting a loan to purchase jetpots, Bingo stamps, and a Bingo machine for her business. She had one previous loan from SPBD. She expects to earn about 250 Tala (about 104 USD) profit per week. SPBD loans are Toeafe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase jetpots, Bingo stamps, and a Bingo machine

loans.name: Samalaulu

texts.en:
Samalaulu V., 55, is married and has 9 children. She has many years of experience as a vegetable farmer. She sells vegetables to the villagers 3 days per week. Her husband helps her run her business. She expects her weekly profit to be 400 Tala (about 166 USD).

She has repaid three previous loans from SPBD. SPBD loans are Samalaulu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She is requesting a loan to purchase supplies for her farming business, such as chemicals, pesticides, and vegetable seeds.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, pesticides, and vegetable seeds for farm

loans.name: Valelia

texts.en:
Valelia S., 49, is married and has 4 children. She has many years of experience growing and selling taro and bananas. She sells to the villagers and the public 2 days per week.

Valelia is a very active woman who puts all of her energy into her business because it is her family's major source of income. She is requesting a loan to purchase supplies for her plantation, such as chemicals, a back sprayer, fertilizer, and bush knives. She would also like to use part of the loan to purchase supplies and tools (such as bricks, cement, galvanized nails, and a hammer) to make some home repairs.

She expects to earn a weekly profit of 300 Tala (about 125 USD). She had 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Valelia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, back sprayer, fertilizer, bush knives for the taro and banana plantation

loans.name: Sinaua

texts.en:
Sinaua A., 25, is married. She has many years of experience in the Elei printing business. She sells Elei, Samoan screen printed material, to the villagers and the public 2 days per week. She expects to earn a weekly profit of 250 Tala (about 104 USD).

Sinaua is requesting her first loan from SPBD. SPBD loans are Sinaua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She plans to use the loan to purchase paint, raw materials, and carved wood designs to make more Elei to sell.

loans.use: Purchase paint, raw materials, and carved wood designs for Elei material

loans.name: Feeonuu

texts.en:
Feeonuu W., 34, is married and has 5 children. She has been running a general store for 5 years. Her store is open 7 days a week to sell food to the villagers.

Feeonuu is an experienced business woman, and she is fully committed to her business. Her store provides the major financial support for her family. She expects her weekly profit will be 540 Tala (about 225 USD).

She is requesting a loan to purchase a freezer for her store, and food items to sell, such as sugar, rice, salt, lamb chops and chicken thighs to sell and increase her profits. She has repaid 1 previous loan from SPBD. SPBD loans are Feeonuu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a freezer; sacks of sugar, rice, and salt; cases of lamp chops and chicken thighs to sell in general store

loans.name: Faamanu

She is requesting a loan to purchase tomato, round cabbage, and pumpkins seeds to plant on her farm. She plans to use some of the loan to purchase supplies, such as nails, galvanized iron, and cement for home repairs also.

She has repaid 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly profit will be 550 Tala (about 229 USD). SPBD loans are Faamanu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase barbed wire and seeds to increase produce to sell

loans.name: Janet

She expects her weekly profit to be 300 Tala (about 125 USD). SPBD loans are Janet’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.name: Alofa

texts.en: Alofa T., 58, is married with nine children. She has many years of experience in the plantation and livestock business, with an averaged expected weekly net income of 500 Tala (~200 USD).  She sells her goods to the villagers and public twice each week. Alofa has had four previous loans through SPBD; these loans are Alofa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to expand and improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase pesticides, barbed wire and other supplies for her plantation and livestock business.

loans.name: Vao

texts.en: Vao L., 50, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells her crops to the villagers and public two days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD, and she expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~180 USD). SPBD loans are Vao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase supplies for her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase pesticides, barbed wire, nails, and other supplies for her plantation.

loans.name: Leonia

texts.en: Leonia T., 54, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the cattle and vegetable business. She sells to the villgers and public two days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD). SPBD loans are Leonia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to improve her business; her husband will also help her out to operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase pesticides, barbed wire, nails and vegetable seeds for her farm and garden.

loans.name: Atiae

texts.en: Atiae F., 39, is married with four children. She has many years of experience making banana chips, which she sells to the public four days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Atiae’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to stock up on inventory for her business.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable oil, plastic papers and bananas to make banana chips

loans.name: Pamata

texts.en: Pamata V., 44, is married with five children.  She has many year of experience in the taro-growing business. She sells to the villagers and the public two days per week and has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~62 USD). SPBD loans are Pamata’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy weed killer, barbed wire, nails, fertilizer, bush knives, and transportation. Pamata's husband is a musician who is the only other income earner of the family. He will sometimes work on the plantation when he is available.

loans.use: Purchase weed killer, fertilizer, and other agricultural implements for her farm.

loans.name: Litiana

texts.en: Litiana F., 30, is married with four children. She has five years of experience in the BBQ business; she sells to the public three days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD). These loans are Litiana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for her children's educational needs, running her business and improving her home.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her BBQ business and provide for her children's education.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of perfumes, beauty products, clothing and other goods for a small general store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To replenish a mini-market.
