loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a small business selling jewelry, shoes and beauty products.

loans.name: Ajmal

texts.en:
Ajmal, son of A. H., graduated from high school last year. He is 23 and has three children. Ajmal and his family returned to Afghanistan in 2002 from 18 years of living in refugee camps in neighboring Pakistan. Ajmal and his extended family live in Jalalabad city of the eastern Ningarhar province.

Ajmal originally wanted to go to college and enter medical school; however, due to economic difficulties surrounding his household, he was not able to pursue his higher education goals. Instead of taking the college tests, he had to turn to his father’s retail shop to make a living. His father’s business, however, is not big enough to support the whole household, including Ajmal’s wife and kids.

Ajmal has decided to join his father’s business and enlarge the store’s inventory to increase profitability. With taking out a loan, Ajmal will be able to not only increase the family store’s daily profit and support the cost of living for the household, but also be able to pursue his educational goals. He will attend to the shop half the day and go to college the second half. He has applied for a 50,000 Afghani loan to achieve this goal.

loans.use: To buy many things for his shop

loans.name: Mach

texts.en:
Mrs. Mach P. is a 34-year-old mother of four in Doek Peang in Kampong Speu Province. She is a grocer and farmer. Previously, Mrs. Mach P. obtained a loan from AMK to start her grocery business. Since her business is going very well, Mrs. Mach P. wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for another loan in order to purchase more grocery goods for her customers.

Her husband, Mr. Thy Chuong, is a construction worker and he always assists his wife business activities. Last year one member of the family was in a motorbike accident and Mrs. Mach P. spent $200 to care for them. Because of this, Mrs. Mach P. has insufficient money to expand her grocery business. Mrs. Mach P. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery goods for her customers.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mr. Van T. is an oxen merchant living in Veal Kreal Village, Kampong Cham Province, where he is married and has five children, four of whom are married. T. buys oxen from farmers in the area and resells them for profit, earning about $1.20 per day. Because he wishes to expand his business, he is requesting a loan to add to his savings to purchase more oxen to sell.

loans.use: To help purchase more oxen to sell.

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Mrs. Thy S. is a widow living in Phnom Penh City, where she buys lotuses from farmers to resell for profit in the market, earning about $3.50 per day. She has six children, all of whom are living in the family home. One of her daughters is a garment worker who helps support family expenses. However, due to increasing expenses, Mrs S. needs to increase her income, so she is requesting a loan to purchase fishing tools for her son and to expand her lotus-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools for her son and expand her lotus-selling business.

loans.name: Pualoa

texts.en: Pualoa - known as Losi - Ulafala, 39, is married with three children. Her husband works for the government as a public servant. She has 2 years of experience in the groceries business. Losi sells to the village people and general public 7 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD). SPBD loans are Losi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with her family's expenses.

loans.use: Pualoa would like to to restock her existing grocery store.

loans.name: Taunese

texts.en: Taunese A., 25, is married with one child. Her husband helps out with the business doing the elei. She has 3 years of experience in the clothing and elei materials business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Taunese’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Taunese's earnings will be used to start her own elei business and help out with the family's expenses.

loans.use: Taunese would like to start her own elei business.

loans.name: Epi

texts.en: Epi P., 35, is married with three children. She has 5 years of experience in the handicrafts business and her husband helps her. She sells to the village and general public 2 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Epi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Epi's earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with her family's expenses.

loans.use: Epi would like to upgrade her crafts business and help repair her house, as well as pay for her kids' school fees.

loans.name: Sayed Ghulam

texts.en:
Sayed Ghulam S. grew up in refuge in neighboring Pakistan during the Afghan civil wars. His father is an old and weak man, so Ghulam S. as a boy was virtually the only breadwinner and had to work hard to support his 8-member family. The family had rented a small store for Ghulam, which he tended to full-time, 7 days a week. The business went well and Ghulam was soon able to purchase that store.

After the fall of the Taliban, Ghulam and his family decided to return to their homeland, Afghanistan. They are residents of the eastern Ningarhar province. Ghulam is pursuing the same business of retail in Afghanistan, but the business is not going well because the inventory is too small for his clientele.

Ghulam S. hopes to expand his business and therefore his profitability by increasing his store inventory. Increase of inventory will also make the business interesting as he is bored and almost fed up with the size of the business he has right now. Sayed Ghulam S. has applied for a 50,000 Afghanis loan to achieve this goal. Ghulam hopes that by increasing his business, he will be able to support his family, send his siblings to school, and watch them become doctors and engineers.

loans.use: To buy enough things for his shop

loans.name: Surita

texts.en: Surita I., 32, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the handicrafts business and her husbands helps her with the business. She sells to the village and general public 3 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Surita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her crafts business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Surita would like to upgrade her crafts business and help repair her family's house.

loans.name: Aliitasi

texts.en: Aliitasi A., 36, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. food making and selling business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD). SPBD loans are Aliitasi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Aliitasi would like to purchase flour, sugar, soy sauce, onions and other stuff to improved her cooking business.

loans.name: Asiasiga

texts.en: Asiasiga F., 55, is married with five children. She has many years of experience in the pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. making and selling business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~$125 USD). SPBD loans are Asiasiga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Asiasiga would like to purchase flour, sugar, salt, onion, soy sauce and also flavors for her ice cake for her food making and selling business.

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en: Epifania M., 30, is married with one child. Her husband works as an operator at Yazaki wiring harness company. She has 3 years of experience in the pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. making and selling business. She sells them to the village and general public 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~$125 USD).  SPBD loans are Epifania’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Epifania would like to improve her business.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng H. is a widowed farmer living in DauSok Village, Siem Reap Province. Her daughter, Miss Prum Aun, is a pig raiser, and their combined income of $3.33 per day helps to support the family’s expenses. Now Mrs. H. wants to develop a sustainable farming business and is requesting a loan to purchase two oxen to use to plough her farmland. The loan will allow her to increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen to plough her farmland.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan C. sells Cambodia noodles in Anlong Chambok Village, Siem Reap Province, earning about $2.66 per day. Her husband is a fisherman in Tonlesap Lake, a livelihood he has pursued since he was 18 years old. They live with four children, all too young to find income to help support the family.  Because of the rising cost of living, Mrs. C. needs to increase the family’s income, and so is requesting a loan to purchase a boat for use in her husband’s fishing business. The remainder of the loan will be used to purchase more rice to make Cambodia noodles.

loans.use: To purchase a boat for her husband's fishing business and more rice to make Cambodia noodles.

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese P., 34, is married with one child. She has 5 years of experience in the handicrafts business and her husband helps out with the business doing the carving and crafting. She sells to the village and general public 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Akenese’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve business and help out with family.

loans.use: Akenese would like to purchase varnish, paint, etc. for her handicrafts business.

loans.name: Moevao

She sells to the village and general public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD).  SPBD loans are Moevao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Moevao would like to buy fertilizer, barred wire, bush knives and also labour for her plantation farm.

loans.name: Salafai

texts.en: Salafai U., 72, is married with eight children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business growing taro, yams, and bananas. She sells to the village and general public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD).  SPBD loans are Salafai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Salafai would like to make home improvements and pay for her kids' school fees.

loans.name: Vaioalisi

texts.en: Vaioalisi F., 47, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village and general public 4 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. Vaioalisi expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Vaioalisi's earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Vaioalisi would like to improve her business, make some repairs to her home and and help pay her childrens' school fees.

loans.name: Vaiutu

texts.en: Vaiutu L., 37, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in cooking taro, taamu, banana, and palusami and selling it as her business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Vaiutu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Vaiutu would like to make home improvements, get transportation for delivering her goods to the market, and school fees for her children.

loans.name: Koreta

texts.en: Koreta P., 56, is married with five children. She has many years of experience in the groceries business. She sells to the village and general public 6 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Koreta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Koreta's earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Koreta would like to buy stocks for her grocery business.

loans.name: Tolusefulu

texts.en: Tolusefulu I., 52, is married with six children. Her husband does the fishing and gets some help from his two boys. She has many years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village and general public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD). SPBD loans are Tolusefulu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her fishing business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Tolusefulu would like to purchase another fishing net and canoe for fishing and also to improve his home.

loans.name: Suemalo

texts.en: Suemalo F., 47, is married with ten children. Her husband and children work a plantation. She has many years of experience making pancakes, porkcakes, ice cakes, etc. and selling them for her business. She sells to the village and general public 5 days per week. Suemalo has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Suemalo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will be used to improve her business and help out with family expenses.

loans.use: Suemalo would like to improve her business status and help to improve her home.

loans.name: Bisolima

texts.en:
Bisolima K., 44, is a widow and has two children. She has almost never had anyone's assistance in helping her children get ahead, so for 21 years, she has been working sewing dresses in a tailor shop. This has been her only income to support and educate her children, and it has not been easy for her to have the entire responsibility for her family. But her love for her children is what drives her forward from day to day.

Bisolima’s work is specialized: sewing European-style dresses for women as well as dresses in the national style. During her long years of activity, she has gained a rich experience in tailoring.

Bisolima herself purchases the fabrics required for sewing in the local market of “Korvon”. On average she sews four dresses and makes an income of 100-120 Somoni (about US$ 30-35) a day.

Bisolima always dreamed of owning a business and not having to depend on anyone else. She believes that someday her dream will come true and she will open her own tailor shop. Today she is requesting a loan of 3400 Somoni (US$ 1000), which she will repay over 6 months, in order to purchase modern fabrics for sewing dresses.

Bisolima is counting on your help. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dream become reality.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for sewing national dresses

loans.name: Muazamkhon

texts.en:
Muazamkhon L., 40, is married with four children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Muazamkhon and her husband work hard to ensure the best future for their children. Muazamkhon has been running her own small business for seven years already. She has a place near a store named “Tuhfaho” for selling ice cream. She works from 8:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m. Her daughter helps her in the store, registering the stock and serving the customers. The business is stable which allows her to improve living conditions for her family.

This year Muazamkhon’s daughter is finishing school and dreaming of entering the university. In order to make her daughter’s dream come true, however, Muazamkhon needs to expand her business. With this purpose in mind, she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 600. Muazamkhon is planning to spend the loan to purchase an extra deep-freezer so as to increase the range of goods she sells. She promises to repay the loan within 12 months and thanks everybody who decides to support her.

Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to help her make her daughter’s dream become reality. With your help, this will be possible.

loans.use: Purchasing a deep-freezer to expand her business

loans.name: Pom

texts.en: Mrs. Pom S., 37, lives in Deok Peang Village in Kampong Speu Province, where she is a Chinese noodle seller and grocer. Her husband, Mr. San Sou, is a construction foreman. They have four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while two others are attending the local school. The youngest is of preschool age.  Since her grocery business is doing very well, Mrs. Pom S. is requesting a loan in order to expand the products she can offer to her customers.  Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods to sell.

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mrs. Mai Y., 24 and the mother of a preschool aged child, lives in Doek Peang Village in Kampong Speu Province, selling grocery goods and breeding pigs. Her husband, Mr. Meng Bun, works in a rice mill where he can make only a small income to support his family. Despite her business activities, Mrs. Mai Y. still does not have enough money to purchase more grocery products for her customers, so she is requesting a loan for this purpose. Previously, Mrs. Mai Y. obtained a loan to start her pig-breeding business. Mrs. Mai Y. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products for her customers.

loans.name: Neourn

texts.en: Mrs. Neourn E. is a farmer in Trapaing Skun Village in Kampong Speu Province. Her husband, Mr. Pheap Choch, is a construction worker who also assists her on the farm. They have four children, three of whom are enrolled in school while the youngest one is of preschool age. Mrs. Neourn E. cannot support her family well because she and her husband earn only a small income, so she is requesting a loan to buy a cow and start a breeding business in order to improve her family’s living conditions. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow and start a breeding business in order to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.name: Thi Nam

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Nam is 30 years old. She has two school-going children. Before joining the TYM Fund, she stayed at home to do farming while her husband worked as a factory worker in Vinh Phuc industrial zone. In 2003, realising that the demand for germinated seeds and young trees in the area was increasing, she discussed with her husband and joined the Fund to borrow money to invest in stock-breeding trees to sell to local people. As she is responsible and quick in doing business, her business is expanding and so her family's income is also increasing. Currently, apart from working in the factory, Her husband also contributes to the business by delivering the germinated seeds and young trees to the customers, thus cutting down the transportation cost. This way, their profit is higher. This time round, she wants to borrow 15 millions VND (900USD) to invest in buying a variety of seeds to germinate and breed and sell to the local people in the next growing season. Her family's average monthly income is 3.5 millions VND (about 226USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Nam năm nay 30 tuổi. Gia đình chị hiện có 2 con đang tuổi đi học. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương chị ở nhà làm công việc chăn nuôi còn chồng chị là công nhân lao động tại khu công nghiệp của Vĩnh Phúc. Năm 2003 nhận thấy nhu cầu về cây giống ở địa phương tăng cao chị đã bàn với chồng tham gia Quỹ Tình thương để vay vốn đầu tư vào ươm, nuôi trồng cây giống để bán cho người dân địa phương. Do biết cách nắm bắt cơ hội làm ăn và luôn giữ uy tín đối với khách hàng nên công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đã ngày càng ổn định và phát triển do đó thu nhập của gia đình chị ngày càng tăng cao, cuộc sống của gia đình ngày càng được cải thiện. Hiện nay ngoài thời gian đi làm tại khu công nghiệp chồng chị cũng hỗ trợ chị trong việc vận chuyển cây giống cho khách hàng vì thế gia đình cũng tiết kiệm được tiền vận chuyển giúp cho thu nhập tăng cao hơn. Vòng vốn này chị mong muốn được vay 15 .000.000 đ để đầu tư vào việc mua các loại giống cây để ươm và bán cho người dân địa phương trong vụ mùa tới. Thu nhập bình quân 3.500.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Growing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Mrs. Lim S. lives in Trapaing Skun Village in Kampong Speu Province, where she is a subsistence farmer. Her husband, Mr. Mean Om, collects palm juice to produce palm sugar for sale. They have five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one is attending school. The remaining two are of preschool age.

Mrs. Lim S.’s family now lives in poor conditions, so she is requesting a loan to start a cow-breeding business in order to improve her standard of living. Mrs. Lim S. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To start a cow-breeding business in order to improve her standard of living.

loans.name: Thi Hang

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Hang is 30 years old. She has 3 school-going children. She joined the TYM Fund in 2000 and borrowed 1 million VND to invest in her clothes shop in the market. Even though the loan was small, it helped to increase her family's income as it was used effectively. Since then, she has borrowed increasing amounts to further invest in her clothes business. As she is friendly and charges reasonable prices, she gets more and more customers and so her family's income is increasingly stable. Beside the income from the clothes shop, her family also has additional income from her husband who is working as a driver. Therefore, her family's income is stable and her children can go to school. This time, she wants to borrow 19 millions VND (1,150USD) to purchase more clothes for the shop. Her family's average monthly income is 5 millions VND (about 322USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng năm nay 30 tuổi. Hiện nay gia đình chị có 3 con đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Năm 2000 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay mức vốn 1.000.000 đ để đàu tư vào của hàng bán quần áo tại chợ. Với mức vốn tuy không lớn nhưng do biết cách sử dụng vốn hiệu quả nên thu nhập của gia đình chị đã được cải thiện. Đến nay qua 7 năm tham gia vào Quỹ với các mức vốn vay tăng dần chị đã đầu tư nhiều hơn vào của hàng quần áo của chị. Với giá bán hợp lý và thái độ luôn niềm nở của chị khách hàng đến với cửa hàng của chị ngày càng đông do đó thu nhập của gia đình chị ngày càng ổn định. Ngoài thu nhập từ việc kinh doanh quần áo, gia đình chị còn có thêm thu nhập từ công việc lái xe của chồng chị vì thế kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển, các con của chị đều được ăn học đầy đủ. Vòng vốn tới chj mong muốn được vay thêm 19.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm hàng, quần áo để phục vụ cho khách hàng. Thu nhập bình quân 5.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Invest in clothes business

loans.name: Thi Doan

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Doan is 44 years old. She has 4 children, the oldest one is already working while the other three children are still schooling. She joined the TYM Fund in 1998. Before that, her family's income was mainly from farming. After joining the Fund, she discussed with her husband and decided to borrow money to purchase more cows and buffaloes to breed. After almost 10 years, her family now has a large number of cows and buffaloes. As she and her husband are both hardworking, their family's income is very stable. Their oldest child is also working and has stable income. Apart from the income from farming and breeding, her family also has additional income from her husband's horse-wagon transportation service. Therefore, her family's monthly income is always around 3 millions VND (about 193USD). This time round, she wants to borrow 15 millions VND (900USD) to purchase more cows to increase the income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thi Đoàn năm nay 44 tuổi. Hiện gia đình chị có 4 người con trong đó có 1 người con đã trưởng thành và 3 con đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương năm 1998. Trước khi tham gia vào quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu dựa vào làm ruộng và trồng vườn. Sau khi tham gia vào Quỹ chị đã bàn với chồng vay vốn để mua thêm trâu, bò về chăn nuôi. Qua gần 10 năm tham gia Quỹ Tình thương hiện nay gia đình chi đã có đàn trâu bò với số lượng đáng kể. Nhờ cần cù, chịu khó làm ăn hiện nay kinh tế của gia đình chị rất ổn định. Anh chị đã có 1 con trưởng thành đi làm và có thu nhập ổn định. Hàng tháng ngoài thu nhập từ chăn nuôi, trồng trọt gia đình chị còn có thêm thu nhập từ công việc chở hàng thuê bằng xe ngựa của chồng. Vì vậy thu nhập của gia đình chị luôn ổn định ở mức 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000 đ để mua thêm trâu bò về nuôi phát triển kinh tế gia đình.

loans.use: Breeding cows

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Bac

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Bac is 35 years old. She has joined the TYM Fund since the year 2003. She used the first loan to invest in livestocks but the income was not substantial. Therefore, she used the second loan to invest in buying scrap and recyclable materials to resale to the retailers. As she was experienced in buying scrap from households as well as determined to increase her family's income, she set up a scrap-buying store at home. Her business gets better and her income increases over time. Besides income from the scrap business, every month her husband earns additional income from construction works, thus her two children can go to school. This round of loan she wants to borrow 19 millions VND (1,150USD) to increase her capital so that she can expand her business. Her monthly income is 4 millions VND (about 258USD)

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Bắc năm nay 35 tuổi. Chị tham gia vàoQuỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi nhưng công việc chăn nuôi cho thu nhập không cao. Do vậy vòng vốn sau chị đã sử dụng vốn vào việc đi thu mua phế liệu từ các hộ gia đình về bán lại cho các đại lý. Do tích lũy được nhiều kinh nghiệm từ công việc đi thu mua phế liệu lẻ cùng với quyết tâm phát triển kinh tế gia đình, chị đã mạnh dạn vay vốn để đầu tư vào kinh doanh phế liệu. Hiện nay gia đình chị đã có một cửa hàng đại lý thu mua phế liệu tại gia đình. Công việc làm ăn của gia đình chị ngày càng thuận lợi và cho thu nhập ngày càng cao. Ngoài thu nhập từ đại lý thu mua phế liệu, hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm thu nhập từ công việc đi làm thợ xây của chồng chị, do đó 2 con chị đều được đầu tư cho ăn học đầy đủ. Vòng vốn này chị muốn vay 19.000.000 đ để đầu tư thêm vốn vào cửa hàng thu mua phế liệu mở rộng kinh doanh. Thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Scrap business

loans.name: Hoy

texts.en: Hoy S. farms and raises pigs in Ponleur Preahphos Village, Siem Reap Province, earning about $1.50 per day, while her husband buys chickens from a villager to sell in the market. They have two children, one of whom is married, while the other works in Siem Reap Province, earning about $1.50 per day. Now Mrs. S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to transport the chickens to the market .

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to transport chickens to market.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S. is a grocery seller in Sangke Meanchey Village, Siem Reap Province, while her husband, Mr. Kuy Mengleang, is a house construction worker. They have eight children, four of whom are married. One of their children works with Mr. Mengleang to help support the family’s expenses. Because of increasing transportation costs, Mrs S. is requesting a loan of $400 which, when added to her savings, will permit the purchase of a motorcycle for use in her family, thereby reducing their expenses.  Mrs. S.'s husband is pictured.

loans.use: To help purchase a motorcycle for family use.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Ms.Le Thi T. is 42 years old. She has 2 children that are school age. Before she joined the organization, her family worked in farming and had faced many difficulties. In 1998, she and her husband had decided to join the organization to seek a loan to invest into raising livestock. After seeing no success in the farm animals business, Ms. Le Thi T. and her husband decided to obtain another loan to start a new business. In the beginning, she used the new loan obtained to buy large amounts of manufactured goods to sell to the people in her village and began noticing the business success. After gaining experience with this type of business, she began selling a variety of fresh food products. She saw the demands for fresh food goods in her village and since been investing more into these goods. Everyday her husband buys wholesale and bulk merchandise for her to sell in her home. Ms. Le Thi T. is able to bring in more customers by offering reasonable prices on her merchandises. As a result, her business has been stable and growing. The income of her business is 4.000.000d/month. She is requesting a loan of 15.000.000d to invest into buying more food products and other goods. This will help increase her inventory, selling them to, and meeting the needs and demands of those in her in her village.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lê thị T. năm nay 42 tuổi. Hiện gia đình chị có 2 con đang tuổi đi học. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị dựa vào làm ruộng và chăn nuôi nên gặp không ít khó khăn . Năm 1998 chị đã bàn với chồng tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư thêm vào chăn nuôi. Sau một vòng vốn thu nhập của gia đình từ công việc chăn nuôi tăng lên không nhiều do đó anh chị đã quyết định vay thêm vốn và bắt đầu đầu tư vào kinh doanh. Ban đầu gia đình chị sử dụng vốn để mua một số mặt hàng tạp hóa về bán cho người dân địa phương thu nhập tăng lên đáng kể. Sau một thời gian làm quen với công việc kinh doanh do nắm bắt được nhu cầu tiêu thụ về các loại thực phẩm tươi tại địa phương gia đình chị đã đầu tư vốn để kinh doanh thêm mặt hàng này. Hàng ngày chồng chị đi mua thực phẩm từ các đại lý về cho chị bán tại nhà. Do khéo léo trong việc bán hàng, với giá cả hợp lý nên khách hàng tìm đến cửa hàng của gia đình chị ngày càng nhiều hơn, công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đã dần ổn định và phát triển. Thu nhập của gia đình đạt 4.000.000đ/ tháng Vòng vốn này gia đình chị mong muốn vay thêm 15.000.000đ đầu tư thêm vốn để mua thêm thực phẩm, hàng tạp hóa để phục vụ tốt hơn nhu cầu của người dân địa phương phát triển kinh doanh tăng thêm nhập cho gia đình.

loans.use: Food business

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana T. sells groceries. She is married, but her husband's income from carpentry is not sufficient for Susana and her five children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Susana is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Nguyen Thi C. is 55 years of age. She has 4 grown children. In 2003, she joined the organization to help her invest in buying livestock in which she raises at home. From a small investment, she is able to expand her business after 5 seasons. Presently, she is able to increase her business by raising a variety of farm animals; cows, pigs and chickens all in large amount. Every month, she is able to retain a steady income and her family finance has since been stable. Besides raising livestock, she was able to purchase cows from other countries to breed. All of her children all grown and have job stability. Every month they are able to contribute some of their earnings to the family business. The family past income has gone from being average to a dramatic increase with the business success. This time, she is asking for a loan of 15.000.000d to buy more chickens and cows to raise. A small portion of this loan will be use to buy animal food in bulk at a wholesale price. Her income is 3.500.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Cảnh năm nay 55 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 4 người con đều đã trưởng thành. Năm 2003 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi tại gia đình. Từ việc đầu tư nhỏ lẻ, đến nay sau 5 vòng vốn quy mô chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đã được mở rộng hơn. Hiện nay gia đình chị đã mở rộng và chăn nuôi kết hợp nhiều loại con như trâu bò và lợn gà với số lượng lớn. Hàng tháng công việc chăn nuôi lợn gà của gia đình cho thu nhập rất đều đặn và ổn định. Ngoài việc chăn nuôi lợn gà, gia đình chị còn đầu tư mua bò giống nhập ngoại về nuôi. Các con của chị đều đã trưởng thành có công việc ổn định vì thế hàng tháng đều hỗ trợ thêm cho gia đình. Kinh tế gia đình chị từ trung bình hiện nay đã dần vươn lên ổn định và khá giả. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị mong muốn được vay thêm 15.000.000 đ để đầu tư mua thêm gà, bò về nuôi. Ngoài ra gia đình sẽ sử dụng 1 phần nhỏ để mua thức ăn dự trữ giá rẻ trong vụ mùa để phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi phát triển kinh té. Thu nhập bình quân 3.500.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising and buy Chickens  cows

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: Choun B., 43, lives in Phum Sleng Village, Siem Reap Province, where she is a farmer and pig breeder, earning around $2 per day. Her husband buys oxen from farmers and resells them for profit. They have five children, two of whom are married; two others are in school and one other works with his parents. Mrs. B. wants all of her children to be well-employed.  To that end, she is sending her one daughter to learn to be a tailor and is requesting a loan to pay for her study fees. She hopes her daughter will have a career for life and earn income to help support the family.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's study fees.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy S., 28, and her family live in a small village off of National Road Two about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh.  Chanthy and her husband, Mr. Kunthoeun Ros, 26, have been married since 2003 and have one little daughter.

Mrs. Chanthy has been a garment factory worker for over ten years, while Kunthoeun has been driving a motorbike taxi in Phnom Penh for four years. The couple lives in a small hut and now they want to build a rest room and concrete ground floor of their house, which will give them a cleaner environment in which to raise their child. Chanthy is requesting a loan of US$700 to build the rest room and ground floor.

loans.use: To build one rest room and concrete ground floor of her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Trinh Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. B. is 27 years old. Even though she is young, Ms. B. is accustomed to doing business for a period of time. As of today she has a family with 2 small children. Ms. B. has been a member since 2003. Her first loan was 1.000.000, in which she had invested into the chicken business to help her financially. After 5 years, the used of her initial loan and business experiences, had expanded her business from the initial investment to 60-70.000.000d to operate. As the business is growing every day, the money that is needed to run the business has also risen. She hopes to borrow 19.000.000d to invest into her business, buying more livestock to cater to the locals in her community. Her income is 8.000.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Bắc năm nay 27 tuổi. Tuy còn trẻ nhưng chị Bắc đã làm quen với công việc kinh doanh được một thời gian dài. Hiện nay gia đình chị có 2 con còn nhỏ. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ Tình thương năm 2003. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay 1.000.000 đ để đầu tư thêm vào công việc kinh doanh gà giống của gia đình cho thu nhập ổn định. Đến nay qua 5 năm sử dụng vốn với kinh nghiệm nhiều năm buôn bán con giống hiện nay mô hình kinh doanh của gia đình chị đã phát triển mạnh với số vốn đầu tư lên đến 60 đến 70 triệu đồng. Với mô hình kinh doanh ngày càng phát triển vì thế nhu cầu vầ vốn ngày càng tăng cao. Để đầu tư thêm vốn cho công việc kinh doanh chị mong muốn được vay 19.000.000đ để mua thêm các loại con giống phục vụ nhu cầu của người dân địa phương. Thu nhập bình quân 8.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Bui T. is 49 years old. Her family consists of 4 children, 2 of which are grown. Her husband is a construction worker and makes approximately 1.500.000d/month. The two eldest children are independent and have jobs of their own. She has been a member of this organization since 1997; her first loan was 300.000, in which she used to invest in buying pigs to raise. After seeing the success of her initial investment, she has been investing more into fixing the pig pens and the care of raising pigs. Besides raising pigs, she has been collecting recycling items and selling them to the big company in her town. With the income of her husband, children and businesses, her family is presently financially stable. Her family was able to build a house and their lives has been better. She is requesting a loan of 10.000.000d to remodel, fix and expand the pig pens and buy more pigs to raise. Her present income is 3.000.000d/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Bùi Thị T. năm nay 49 tuổi. Gia đình chị hiện có 4 người con trong đó có 2 con đã trưởng thành. Chồng chị làm nghề thợ xây cho thu nhập khoảng 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Hai con lớn của chị đã đi làm và có thu nhập ổn định. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1997 với vòng vốn ban đầu là 300.000 đ chị đã đầu tư mua thêm lợn về nuôi. Đến nay sau một thời gian dài sử dụng vốn có hiệu quả, gia đình chị đã đầu tư được nhiều hơn vào việc sửa sang chuồng trại phục vụ cho việc chăn nuôi. Ngoài thời gian chăn nuôi tại gia đình, chị còn đi thu mua phế liệu về bán cho các đại lý trong vùng. Cùng với thu nhập của chồng con và công việc tăng thu nhập của chị hiện nay kinh tế gia đình chị đã rất ổn định. Hiện gia đình chị đã tích lũy và xây được căn nhà rất khang trang cuộc sống gia đình chị đã được cải thiện rất nhiều. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 10.000.000đ để sử sang chuồng trại và mua thêm lợn về chăn nuôi. Thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Invest in raising pigs

loans.name: Naran

texts.en:
Miss. Naran P., 40, is single and lives with her parents, brother, and sister. The family lives on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her mother is a silk weaver and her sister is weaving at home as well. Her father does farming and assists with spinning thread and silk. Her brother is in local school.

Miss. Naran has been a silk weaver -- a skill she learned from her mother -- since 1984. The family sells their finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Naran is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase silk material to continue her family’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Matt

texts.en:
Matt M., 35, is a grocer in the Kampong Cham province and lives with her husband, Sun Seit, and their five children. She typically makes US$ 10 in gross income each day, while her husband works at a rubber plantation, making US$ 2 each day. They have noticed that their community has a high demand for their grocery products, but they lack the capital to expand their business to meet this demand.

Matt M. is asking for a loan of US$ 300 to purchase more grocery products to expand her business and meet the growing customer demands. She believes this investment will be a great opportunity for her business and it can continue to grow in the future.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. T. is 37 years of age and has 2 school age children. She has been a member since 2001 and since been requesting loans to raise pigs. The investment has bought her success and she hopes this future loan will enable her and her family to invest into man-made ponds to raise fishes. Presently, she has 5 plat to invest into the fish ponds, 3 sets of cattle’s to mate and reproduce, and her business of raising pigs and selling its meat has been a success. Every day, besides going to the different towns and markets buying and selling farm animals, her husband helps her with the animals and the fish business. She hopes the loan of 19.000.000 VND will help her buy more fishes for reproduction, fish food and supplies needed for the fish ponds. Her income is 5,000,000 VND/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Lynn Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Thuật năm nay 37 tuổi, hiện chị có 2 con đang tuổi đi học. Năm 2001 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư vào dự án chăn nuôi lợn tại gia đình. Từ việc đầu tư dự án có hiệu quả những vòng vốn sau gia đình chị đã mạnh dạn vay vốn đầu tư đấu thầu ao thả cá ở địa phương. Hiện nay ngoài dự án 5 sào ao thả cá với quy trình chăn nuôi khá quy mô và 3 cặp bò sinh sản, gia đình chị còn tập trung nuôi lợn thịt bán rất hiệu quả. Hàng ngày ngoài thời gian đi các vùng lân cận mua bán trâu bò chồng chị dành thời gian để hỗ trợ chị chăn nuôi, trông ao cá. Vòng vốn này chị mong muốn được vay thêm 19.000.000đ để đầu tư mua cá giống và mua thức ăn phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi cá.Thu nhập bình quân 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising fish

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim H., 41, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Bes Nov, and their five children. She works in her field as a farmer making US$ 1 each day, while her husband collects palm juice, making US$ 5 each day. He is then able to take the palm juice and refine it into palm sugar. The family is also supported through the employment of one of their daughters who works in a local garment factory, but the other children are students.

Yim H. has asked for a loan of US$ 300 to purchase another plot of farmland to expand her current rice crops. She believes that this expanded property will yield a profitable harvest for her and she will be able to increase her income and improve her standard of living. She sees this also as a long-term investment opportunity, because the price of land in Cambodia has been rising rapidly, especially out in the rural areas.

loans.use: Purchase farmland

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. Chhoun, 48, and her husband, Mr. Savoeun Chorn, 53, live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh and have been married since the Pol Pot regime. They have five daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home. Of the three children still living at home, one is a silk weaver at home, one is a garment factory worker, and one is in a local school.

Mrs. Y. has been raising pigs since 2003. Before starting this business, she was a silk weaver. Mr. Savoeun has been in the business of producing rice wine since 1979. Y. is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase feeds for raising pigs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi M., aged 54, has two children, one of whom is married and has a secure job. Mrs. M. has joined the TYM Fund for seven years. During the first few years, Mrs. M. used the loans to invest into breeding animals and planting orchard, which helped increase her family’s income very much. After the first two years, Mrs. M. was more confident about asking for more loans to build more breeding facilities for chickens and pigs. She also makes use of food from her orchards to feed the chickens and pigs, helping her save a considerable amount of money to purchase furniture and improve the quality of her family’s life. In the next loan level, Mrs. M. wishes to borrow 10 millions VND to buy more tools for her work. Her family’s income is 3 millions VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Mỹ năm nay 54 tuổi. Hiện gia đình chị có một con đã trưởng thành đã xây dựng gia đình và có công ăn việc làm ổn định. Tính đến thời điểm này chị đã tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương được 7 năm. Những năm đầu tham gia Quỹ gia đình chị vay vốn đàu tư vào chăn nuôi và vườn cây ăn quả của gia đình cho thu nhập tăng lên đáng kể. Qua 2 năm tham gia vay vốn gia đình chị đã mạnh dạn vay thêm vốn đầu tư vào sửa sang chuồng trại để chăn nuôi thêm lợn, gà. Với nguồn thức ăn tận dụng được từ vườn nhà công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình đã cho thu nhập cao. Vì thế gia đình chị đã đầu tư được nhiều hơn cho việc chăn nuôi, mua sắm trang thiết bị, sửa sang nhà cửa. Vòng vốn tiếp theo chị muốn vay thêm 10 triệu đồng để đầu tư mua thêm lợn về chăn nuôi.

Thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Chai

texts.en:
Chai H., 50, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Chhun Oeun, and two of their children. She works on her farmlands growing rice and sewing palm leaves together. She sells the palm leaves as roofing material or as siding for a house and typically makes US$ 2 each day. Her husband makes US$ 1 each day as a farmer as well, growing rice and vegetables in his fields. One of their daughters works in a local garment factory and provides a little extra income for the family, but the family has been seeking out other ways to diversify their income.

They have asked for a loan of US$ 250 to purchase a cow to raise and sell for a profit when it is large enough. They would like to venture into this livestock raising business, and they hope that in the future they can continue to purchase cows to raise and sell. They believe that they can see a solid return on their investment and their income will increase. They hope that this opportunity will allow them to improve their standard of living as well.

loans.use: Purchase a cow

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi M., aged 30, has two children, who are still in school. She joined the TYM Fund in 2003. Since then, Mrs. M. has used the loan from TYM Fund to take care of the pigs. Her husband is a house-builder with a relatively stable income. Due to all the experience she has obtained so far, her agricultural projects usually succeed, leading to a very secure income compared to other families’ income in her neighborhood. Her family’s monthly income is about 3 millions VND. In the next loan level, Mrs. M. wishes to borrow 10 millions VND to purchase more pigs and breed them.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị M. năm nay 30 tuổi. Gia đình chị hiện có 2 con đang trong độ tuổi đi học. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương năm 2003. Hiện nay hàng ngày chị sử dụng vốn vay để chăn nuôi lợn, chồng chị đi làm nghề thợ xây cho thu nhập tương đối ổn định. Với kinh nghiệm tích luỹ được qua nhiều năm trong công việc nuôi lợn thịt và lợn sinh sản dự án đầu tư của gia đình chị luôn cho thu nhập cao và ổn định. Với thu nhập bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng gia đình chị là một trong số hộ có kinh tế ổn định trong thôn.

Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn về nuôi.

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Buth

texts.en:
Buth S., 30, grows rice and vegetable crops in Kampong Cham where she lives with her husband, Enn Yoeun, and their two young children. She typically makes US$ 1.20 each day, while her husband works as a firewood salesman, making US$ 2 each day. Their children are still dependent upon the family, as one is a student in the local school and the other is still too young to attend school.

Buth S. has asked for a loan of US$ 200 to expand her farm through the purchase of more vegetable seeds and fertilizer for her crops. She believes this will be an investment that allows her to increase her income through a greater harvest of her crops and a chance to improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to expand her farm even further, through the purchase of more land, so that she can increase her amount of crops. A future land purchase would also be a great long-term investment, because the price of land in Cambodia has been rising rapidly lately.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., aged 45, has 23 children. Two of her sons are currently working for a telecoms company with a very secure income. She and her husband decided to join TYM Fund in 2000 so that they could take a loan and invest it into agricultural activities such as breeding, planting. Mrs. H. used the money TYM Fund lent her back then to fertilize the soil and build more breeding facilities, which have resulted in a very well-structured system. Her family’s income, as a result, has increased considerably; and they have been able to build a very nice house. Mrs. H. wishes to borrow 15 millions VND in the next loan level to invest into her future project. Her family’s monthly income is 5 millions VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hạnh năm nay 45 tuổi. Hiện gia đình chị có 23 con trong đó có 2 con trai đang làm việc tại công ty viễn thông quân đội cho thu nhập rất ổn định. Năm 2000 chị bàn với chồng tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư chăn nuôi, trồng trọt phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Với lợi thế gia đình có vườn rộng gia đình chị đã vay vốn để đầu tư cải tạo đất vườn, xây dựng chuồng trại để chăn nuôi. Hiện nay gia đình chị đã có khu vực chuồng tại phục vụ chăn nuôi rất quy mô vì thế thu nhập của gia đình ngày càng tăng lên. Do đó hiện tại gia đình chị đã xây dựng được ngôi nhà rất khang trang. Để đầu tư cho dự án chăn nuôi tới, gia đình chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ Thu nhập bình quân 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising and growing

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Moeun S., 28, works as a tailor in Kampong Cham where she lives with her husband, Thai Tha (pictured above), and their two young children. Since she must also take care of the children at home, Moeun S. typically makes US$ 2 each day as a tailor. Her husband raises pigs. Her husband is running a profitable business and they believe that if they are given an opportunity to expand, then they can increase their production to meet customer demands. She has asked for a loan of US$ 300 to build a barn for their pigs, allowing them to raise many more pigs at one time. She believes this investment will increase her family’s income and can improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Build barn for pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Hong

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Hong T., 60, has six children, who are all grown-up. She joined TYM fund in 2003. Initially, Mrs. Hong only took out a small amount of loan to invest into agricultural activities such as breeding and planting in the hope of earning a stable income for her family. After obtaining some experience, Mrs. Hong felt more confident about asking for a bigger amount of loan to revamp the system, build more fish ponds and breeding facilities. Since then, her family’s income has been very stable. When her husband passed away, her determination, diligence and love for her children helped her overcome the grief and keep raising her kids. All of them have already had jobs and helped her with her business. In the next loan level, she wishes to borrow 19 millions VND to buy more fishes and pigs. Her income is 5 millions VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng Thái năm nay 60 tuổi Gia đình chị hiện có 6 con đã trưởng thành. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương từ năm 2003. Ban đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi và trồng trọt, dự án cho thu nhập tương đối ổn định. Sau khi đã tích luỹ được thêm kinh nghiệm trong chăn nuôi gia đình chị đã mạnh dạn vay các vòng vốn lớn hơn để chuyển đổi cơ cấu chăn nuôi, trồng trọt, đào ao thả cá, xây dựng thêm hệ thống chuồng trại để chăn nuôi. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi, thả các theo mô hình trang trại cho thu nhập rất ổn định. Không có được may mắn như những người phụ nữ khác do chồng chết sớm nhưng với bản chất chăm chỉ, chịu khó và quyết tâm làm ăn nuôi con cái khôn lớn chị đã vượt qua được khó khăn. Các con của chị nhờ đó cũng được nuôi dạy trưởng thành. Hiện tại các con chị đều có công việc làm ổn định và đều có thể giúp đỡ thêm cho chị trong việc làm ăn hàng ngày. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 19.000.000đ để đầu tư mua cá giống, mua thêm lợn để chăn nuôi.

Thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising and growing

loans.name: Thi Thao

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Thao (ID number: 050045) is 26 years old. She would like to borrow 2,006,000VND (approximately 125USD) to purchase home products such as bowls and cups to sell. Her husband is a carpenter. They like to join this Fund because they can repay on an installment basis. Their family's average daily income is about 100,000VND (approximately 6.50USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Thao (MS: 050045), năm nay 26 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND lấy vốn bán hàng bát, chén. Chồng chị làm thợ mộc. Anh chị thích tham gia vì được trả tuần. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng 100.000 VND/ngày.

loans.use: Home products retailing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sary S., 51, and her husband, Mr. Hel Phan, 54, live along national road number one about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have three children, one son and two daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home. One daughter is a tailor and the youngest one is in a local school.   

Mrs. Sary has been selling grocery items for seven years. She buys the items from Kor Ky market for resale at her shop in the front of her house. Mr. Hel is in the army. The couple is in the process of repairing their house, and Sary is requesting a loan of $1000 for this purpose.

loans.use: House repair

loans.name: Thi Mon

texts.vi:
Mrs. L. Thi Mon (ID number: 050048) is 67 years old. She would like to borrow 2,006,000VND (approximately 125USD) to do dried goods retailing. Her family has a stabL. income of about 60,000VND (approximately 4USD) per day. She likes to join this Fund because she can repay the loan in an installment basis. Her family has never borrowed from any other Funds.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Lê Thị Môn (MS: 050048), năm nay 67 tuổi. Cô vay 2.006.000 VND để buôn bán hàng khô. Gia đình cô có thu nhập thường xuyên, với mức thu nhập bình quân là 60.000 VND/ngày. Cô thích tham gia chương trình vì được trả dân. Gia đình cô chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đâu.

loans.use: Dried goods retailing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gabil

texts.en: Gabil has been in this business for 11 years. He is 48 years old, married, has 2 children, and has settled in Gala settlement. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Lachin region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. Now he is requesting a loan of US$ 1200 to buy home appliances to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy home appliances for re-sale

loans.name: Thi Cuc

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Cuc (ID number: 050043) is 34 years old. This is the first time she applies for loan. She wants to borrow 2,006,000VND (approximately 125USD) to buy more food for the chickens and fish that she is breeding. She also makes canvas bags to obtain a stable income for her family. Her husband works as a construction worker for additional income. Her family's daily income is about 100,000VND (approximately 6.50USD). She has 3 school-going children. She has never borrowed from any where else.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Cúc (MS: 050043), năm nay 34 tuổi. Chị tham gia vay lần một. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND về mua cám chăn nuôi gà, cá. Bản thân chị đi làm bao tải co thu nhập thường xuyên cho gia đình. Chồng chị đi làm xây dựng giúp gia đình có thêm thu nhập. Anh chị có 3 con hiện còn đang đi học Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị 100.000 VND. Gia đình chị chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đâu.

loans.use: Animal breeding

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Thyda's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thyda V. (shown in picture on the left) was selected by her group members to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. In the group there are six families represented, including hers. They all live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh

1-Miss. Thyda V. (age 24) is single and lives with her old mother and brothers and sisters. Thyda has been a silk weaver since she was eighteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

2-Mrs. VU. U. (age 47) is a widow with two children: one son and one daughter who is married. Her son is a weaver as well. U. has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

3-Mrs. Touch K. (age 40) and her husband were married in 1996 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children are in local school. Touch and her husband have been silk weavers for over ten years, a skill they learned from their neighbor. Touch is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

4-Mrs. Bunleang U. (age 28) and her husband were married in 1998 and have two sons. Bunleang has been silk a weaver for years, a skill she learned from her mother, while her husband has been a carpenter for four years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

5-Mrs. Sanh S. (age 36) and her husband were married in 1998 and have one son who is in local school. Sanh and her husband have been silk weavers for almost twenty years. Sanh is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

6-Mrs. Ly C. (age 55) is a widow with five children: four sons and one daughter. Ly has been a silk weaver since she was fifteen years old, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $100 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Qua

texts.vi:
Mrs. L. Thi Qua (ID number: 030002) is 42 years old this year. She wants to borrow 2,006,000VND (approximately 125USD) to buy more popcorn to sell. Her family has a stable income. The family's average daily income is 70,000VND (approximately 4.50USD). She has two school-going children. She likes to join this Fund because the procedure is simple. Her family had borrowed from the Women's Group before.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Lưu Thị Quả (MS: 030002), năm nay 42. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND bổ sung vốn mua hàng bỏng ngô bán, gia đình có thu nhập thường xuyên. Cô có 2 con còn đang đi học. Mức thu nhập bình quân 70.000 VND/ngày. Cô thích tham gia chương trình vì thủ tục đơn giản. Gia đình cô đã từng vay vốn của hội phụ nữ.

loans.use: Popcorn selling

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Thy T., 43, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Heang Toeu (pictured above), and their eight children. She works in the fields as a farmer and typically makes US$ 1.50 each day, while her husband is a fisherman and makes US$ 8 each day. The family is also supported by the employment of two sons who are local blacksmiths.

Fishing has been difficult this year in Cambodia and inflation problems have impacted all Cambodians. Thy T. has asked for a loan of US$ 700 to purchase some new fishing equipment for her husband's business. With new equipment, he can increase his daily catch and also the family’s daily income. She believes this investment can also help her family improve its standard of living in the long term.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Pannha

texts.en:
Mr. Pannha A. (pictured with his mother), 21, was married early this year and lives with his mother. The family lives on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 
His wife is a garment factory worker.

Mr. Pannha has been a plaster decorator for two years, a skill he learned in Phnom Penh. His business is growing well, but he lacks some money to expand his business. He is requesting a loan of US$400 to purchase plaster materials for housing decoration, which will help him grow his business.

loans.use: To purchase plaster material for housing decoration

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Loan

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Loan (ID number: 020011), is 47 years old this year. This is the second time she applies for loan. She had already repaid the first loan fully. This second time she wants to borrow 2,714,000VND (approximately 175USD) to invest and get more stock for her butcher stall in the wet market. Her husband also helps her with the stall. Her family's daily income is about 100,000VND (approximately 6.50USD). She has a school-going child. Her family has not borrowed from any other Funds. She really likes to join this Fund because she can repay the loan on an installment basis.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Nghiêm Thị Loan (MS: 020011), năm nay 47 tuổi. Cô tham gia vay lần hai. Lần một cô đã hoàn trả xong. Lần hai cô vay 2.714.000 VND bổ sung vốn đi chợ buôn bán thịt lợn. Chồng cô cùng đi chợ giúp cô bán hàng. Thu nhập của gia đình cô khoảng 100.000 VND/ngày. Cô có một con đang đi học. Gia đình cô chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đâu. Cô rất thích tham gia chương trình vì được trả dần.

loans.use: Meat selling

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Morn S., 51, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham with her four children. Two of her daughters work in the Phnom Penh garment factories, earning US$ 130 each month, while one child is a student and the other is still too young to attend school. Morn S. works as a farmer and typically makes US$ 1 each day out in the fields. She would like to cut down on unnecessary expenses and increase her family’s income.

Morn S. has asked for a loan of US$ 300 to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to use to commute to work. She has seen how the price of public transportation has risen rapidly with the increase in gas prices and she believes that the family can save some money through this purchase. She would like to see her standard of living improved through the increased income and looks forward to the results of this investment.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Be Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Be Thi N. (SEDA ID: 020033) is 34 year old. She borrows 2,006,000 Vietnamese Dong for her plans of raising chickens and farming. Her husband, a construction worker, also contributes to the family earning. Her five children are still at school age. The family incomes are 100,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $ 6.3, a day.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Bé (MS: 020033), năm nay 34 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND về chăn nuôi gà và bổ sung vốn phục vụ nông nghiệp. Chồng chị đi làm xây dựng cũng giúp có thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị có 5 con vẫn còn nhỏ và đang đi học. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng 100.000 VND/ngày.

loans.use: Raise chichens and do general farming works.

loans.name: Sothy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothy U., 40, and her husband, Mr. Yong Aum,45, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, and have been married for twenty years. They have seven children: three sons and four daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home. Two of her children are in school and two other children weave silk at home.

Mrs. Sothy has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother, while Mr. Yong does farming and raises cows. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh.

Sothy is requesting a loan of US600 to purchase silk material to continue her family’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Yu

texts.en:
Yu S., 54, typically makes US$ 10 each day as she sells pork, beef, rice, and Chinese noodles for breakfast, along with soft drinks and coffee. She lives in Prey Veng with her husband, Kung Chandara, and four of their children. Her husband helps with his wife’s business and together they have been looking for ways to diversify their income and improve their standard of living.

Yu S. has asked for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a car for one of her sons. With this new vehicle her son could operate his own taxi service, providing a new source of income for the family. She believes this investment will allow the family to increase its income in the long-term and looks forward to seeing how this money can be used.

loans.use: Purchase a car to run a taxi service

loans.name: Milly Lwanga’S Group

texts.en:
Milly L. is the leader of a group of five women. She is 47 years old and is married with five children. Her children are ages 15, 20, 23, 25, and 27 years old, and are all in school. Milly lives in Lower Nsooba, which is a semi-urban slum on the outskirts of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Milly has worked in her house making brushes for over 30 years. The market for her products is fair. The most challenging part of her business is the lack of timber to make the brushes.

With this loan, Milly plans on buying additional raw materials for making brushes to increase her stock. Since she began working with MCDT, Milly has been able to grow her business, support her family, and educate her children.

Milly has successfully paid back 13 loans since she began working with MCDT.

loans.use: Buy raw materials to make more brushes

loans.name: Dan Thi Nghiem's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dan Thi N. (SEDA ID: 020012) is 23 year old. She borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy inventory wood, producing table and chair sets. She is also raising pigs to have some extra income. Her 2 sons are still at school age. Her family incomes are about 110,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $6.93, per day. She has participated in one loan term and repaid the loan on time.

Mrs. Hoa Thi Nguyen (SEDA ID: 020014) is 24 year old. She borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise pigs.

These two individuals sign a group loan contract.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nghiêm Thị Dân (MS: 020012), năm nay 23 tuổi. Chị vay 2.242.000 VND về bổ sung vốn mua gỗ để làm bàn ghế. Chị đang chăn nuôi lợn để phụ giúp gia đình có thêm thu nhập. Chị có 2 con nhỏ vẫn đang đi học. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng 110.000 VND/ ngày. Chị đã tham gia được một chu kỳ vốn và hoàn trả rất tốt. Chị Nguyễn Thị Hoa (MS: 020014), năm nay 24 tuổi. Chị vay 2.242.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: Producing table and chair sets, and raising pigs

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
Nuon O., 55, is a widow who lives in Prey Veng with her one child. She sells vegetables out of her home and typically makes US$ 2 each day. Inflation has been a very difficult problem for Cambodians and inconsistent weather patterns have recently hurt farmers.

NO. O. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a water pump to irrigate her farmland. This will help both with crop production and quality. With any leftover monies, she would like to purchase some fertilizer and gasoline to help with her family’s expenses. She believes this opportunity will allow her to increase her income and looks forward to reaping the benefits of this investment.

loans.use: Purchase water pump; fertilizer; gasoline

loans.name: Ha Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Ha Thi N. (SEDA ID: 020013) is 25 year old. She borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy inventory wood for her plan of producing small wooden items. She has anticipated in 1 loan term and repaid the loan on time. Her family incomes are 100,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $6.3, per day

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hà (MS: 020013), năm nay 25 tuổi. Chị vay 2.242.000 VND để bổ xung vốn mua gỗ làm hàng đục gọt. Chị đã tham gia được một chu kỳ vay vốn và hoàn trả rất tốt. Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị là 100.000 VND/ngày.

loans.use: Produce small wooden items

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem S., 30, cooks and sells rice and other foods out of her home in Prey Veng. She lives with her husband, Uth Moa, and their three children, making US$ 2.50 each day. Her husband works as a construction foreman in Phnom Penh and typically makes US$ 2.50, but his business could be improved and expanded with a few purchases.

Sem S. has asked for a loan of US$ 500 to invest in her husband’s business and to purchase some construction tools to facilitate his work. With some new equipment, the family believes its income can be increased and their standard of living can be improved. They are looking forward to the results of this investment and are grateful for the opportunity it provides for them.

loans.use: Purchase construction tools

loans.name: Nga Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nga Thi N. (SEDA ID 020059) is 33 year old. She borrows 2,714,000 Vietnamese Dong for her plan of raising small farming animals and making tofu. Her 2 sons are still at school age. She has borrowed the loan once and repaid on time. At the moment, the family frequent incomes are at level of 100,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $6.93, per day.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Nga (MS: 020059), năm nay 33 tuổi. Chị vay 2.714.000 VND để chăn nuôi, làm đậu phụ. Gia đình có thu nhập thường xuyên. Chị đã vay vốn một lần và hoàn trả rất tốt. Chị có hai con đang đi học. Mức thu nhập bình quân 110.000 VND/ngày.

loans.use: Raise small farming animals and make tofu

loans.name: Sithon

texts.en:
Mrs. Sithon K., 35, and her husband, Mr. Chea Sok, 38, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, and have been married for over ten years. They have three children: one son and two daughters. One of their children is in a local school.

Mrs. Sithon has been a silk weaver since she was twenty years old, a skill she learned from her mother, while Mr. Chea has been a silk weaver since he was married. He learned his skill from his wife. The couple sells their finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh.

Sithon is requesting a loan of US$200 to purchase silk material for her husband’s loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Fatou G. is a married woman and mother of three. She has been selling things for almost 8 years, and her clientele is made up of women from her neighborhood. Her business consists of buying fabric that she sews in order to resell them in the local market, with a portion of it sold in Mali. When she goes to Mali, she is also able to stock up on “thioup” fabric and other different products with the goal of diversifying her business and increasing her income.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

fatou G. est une femme mariée et mère de trois enfants .elle fait du commerce depuis presque 8 ans et sa clientèle est composée des femmes de son quartier.son activité consiste à acheter des tissus qu'elle fait coudre pour les revendre sur le marché local et une partie est vendue au mali .en plus si elle se rend au mali elle en profite pour s'approvisionner en tissus "thioup" et produits divers dans le but de diversifier ses activités et améliorer ses revenus.

loans.use: the purchase of fabrics with which to make women's clothes

loans.name: Makhammad

texts.en: Makhammad is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Djabrayil region. He is married and settled with his 2 children in the Absheron region. He is a history teacher at school. He has been in the history tutoring business for 11 years. Now he  is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to buy a computer.

loans.use: to buy a computer

loans.name: Hing

texts.en:
Mrs. Hing N., 51, and her husband, Mr. Lo Pang , 72, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1975 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home. 

Mrs. Hing has been a weaver for twenty-five years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Lo grows rice and vegetables.

Hing is requesting a loan of US$900 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim S., 54, has worked with her husband growing rice on her rice field since 1979. Besides working on the rice paddy, her husband also works as a traditional musician.

In Cambodia, there are a number of ceremonies, parties, wedding parties and other festivals and celebrations during a year. A traditional musician is hired to perform at each ceremony to make the occasion more traditional and enjoyable. Sim S.'s husband is sometimes asked to perform traditional music when there is a ceremony or celebration in his town. With the additional US$ 5 per day he makes from his work, he normally invests in his farming and pays his family’s expenses.

Now Mrs. Sim S. and her husband would like to purchase a cow to assist in plowing their paddy and also farming necessities such as fertilizer and insecticide. She believes the help from this loan will positively impact her family and enable her to expand and harvest more crops.

Sim S. has seven children. Three of them are single and the rest are married. (She is pictured with her husband and two grandchildren.)

loans.use: to purchase a cow, fertilizer, and insecticide

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhun C., 34, and her husband, Mr. Chan Chok , 30, live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. They were married in 2000 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them are in a local school. 

Mrs. Sokhun has been a weaver since 1987, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Chan has a new job constructing wooden houses. Before started this business, he was also a silk weaver.

Sokhun is requesting a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work. Good transportation will allow him to spend more time on the job instead of being in transit.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sophois

texts.en:
Mr. Sophois M., 28, and his wife, Mrs. Sokhorn Sous, 26, live along national road number one about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Theywere married in 2000 and have three children: one son and two daughters. 

Mr. Sophois has been an electrician for three years. He does his job in the village and in Phnom Penh City. Mrs. Sokhorn sells Khmer noodles in the village. Sophois is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorcycle so he can to work more easily and spend less time in transit.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for transportation to work

loans.name: Hoa Thi Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hoa Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050037), is 44 year old. She borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy inventory wood for her plan of producing tables. She, along with the group, has participated in 1loan term and repaid on time. After the first time borrowing money to raise small farming animals, she could save some money. Therefore, she wants to keep on participating in the program. Her family incomes are 120,000 Vietnamese Dong, approximately $7.56, per day. She has 3 children, who are also contributing to the family budget.

In the group, there are the following individuals:

Mrs. Chuyen Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050036) borrows 2,714,000 Vietnamese Dong to participate in beef retailing in the local market.

Mrs. Sau Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050038) borrows 2,006,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise pigs and buy and sell metal waste.

Mrs. Nguyet Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050040) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise chickens and pigs.

Mrs. Ngu Thi L. (SEDA ID: 050041) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise chickens.

Mrs. Tha Thi N. (SEDA ID: 050037) borrows 2,242,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy and sell firewood.
