Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Cô Nguyễn Thị Hoa (MS: 050037), năm nay 44 tuổi. Cô vay 2.242.000 VND bổ sung vốn mua gỗ để đóng bàn. Cô cùng cả nhóm đã tham gia được một chu kỳ vay và đã hoàn trả rất tốt. Lần một cô vay để chăn nuôi và thấy mình tiết kiệm được. Vì vậy cô tiếp tục tham gia chương trình. Mức thu nhập của gia đình cô là 120.000 VND/ngày. Cô có 3 con đã đi làm giúp đỡ được cô rất nhiều trong việc chi tiêu cho gia đình.

  • Trong nhóm cô còn có:
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Chuyền (MS: 050036), vay 2.714.000 VND để mua thịt bò bán ở chợ.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Sáu (MS: 050038), vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn và bổ sung vốn đi buôn phế liệu.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Nguyệt (MS: 050040), vay 2.242.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà, lợn.
  • Chị Lê Thị Ngữ (MS: 050041), vay 2.242.000 VND để chăn nuôi gà.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Thả (MS: 050039), vay 2.242.000 VND để mua củi bán.

loans.use: Agricultural product sales; table production, and raising

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more grocery products to meet her growing customer demand

loans.name: Sarah Kitata’S Group

texts.en:
Sarah K. is the leader of a group of four women. Sarah is 39 years old and is divorced with four children, ages 16, 18, 20, and 22. Due to the high cost of school fees, only one of her children is currently in school. Sarah lives in a semi-urban slum on the outskirts of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Sarah has been selling charcoal for the past four years in Kawempe. The market for the charcoal she sells is fair. She faces the challenge of limited money to expand her business, support her family, and pay rent on her house, despite the fact that she works hard.

Sarah plans on using this loan to increase her stock by purchasing more charcoal. With the profits, Sarah will continue to provide the basic needs for her children and pay school fees. Sarah's dream is to one day be able to afford to buy a plot of land and build a house for her family.

Sarah has successfully paid back five loans to MCDT. It is through these loans that she has been able to keep her business operating.

loans.use: To increase stock of charcoal

loans.name: Paulina Nantongo`s Group

texts.en:
Paulina is the leader of a group of five women. She is 32 years old and married with 3 children, ages 5 months, 10 years, and 14 years. Her two eldest children are in school, the youngest is an infant. She lives in an urban community which is highly susceptible to floods during the rainy season.

Paulina has been selling shoes in the market near her home six days a week, Monday through Saturday for the past five years. Her market for shoes is fair. The biggest challenge is few customers. She has been able to augment her shoe business by also selling soda, water, and passion fruit.

Paulina plans on using this loan to increase her stock of shoes and drinks. She hopes to one day be able to buy a plot and build a house.

Paulina has successfully paid back 10 loans.

loans.use: Increase stock of shoes and drinks

loans.name: Tanut Group

texts.en:
This group`s name is Tanut. Saudatu K. is its leader. She is 28, born in Makalie, married to a tailor and they have 1 child. Saudatu has been selling foodstuffs for the past 3 years now.

The other members include: Mariama K. who sells various articles and Fatmata K. who sells palm oil.

Previous loans helped these women a great deal both domestically and in increasing the size of their businesses. Having completed repaying their loans to SMT successfully, they are thus asking for a new loan of US$ 775 to further enlarge their businesses.

loans.use: Buy more items to increase  the size of their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami was born in 1955. He is married, has 4 children, and is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Lachin region, and is settled in the Absheron region. 15 years ago, he started this business. Now he needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy meat to expand his butchery business.

loans.use: to buy meat for re-sale

loans.name: Pring

texts.en:
Mr. Pring S., 47, is married with five children and works as a construction foreman, making on average around $3 per day. His wife works selling fish at Phsar Prek Pnov market near her town. She purchases fish wholesale from fisherman at a river dock and then resells them for a profit. Some of the fish are sold fresh and some are dried before being sold. She can make about $4 each day of net income.

Now Mr. Pring S. would like to change his business from working as a construction foreman to driving a moto-taxi to transport passengers from place to place in his town. Because construction work is irregular and the income he makes is inconsistent and barely enough to support his household, he would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase a motor-bike with a trailer attached to transport passengers in his town. He feels sure the trailer business will go well and earn his family a lot of money.

His wife is pictured because Mr. Pring S. is not available.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a moto-taxi with trailer attached

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane E. is 46-years-old and is married with six children. She lives in Benin City with her family where she runs a hardware store. She worked in this field for two years and started her own business in 2002. Jane is asking for a loan to buy more building materials and hardware products  for her store. She is a LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more building materials and hardware products for resale

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter O. is 30-years-old and single. He lives in Benin City where he sells building materials. He worked in this business for two years before opening his own store in 2003. Peter has been a LAPO client for the past for 4 years. He is requesting a loan to purchase more building materials for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials for resale

loans.name: Mary Najjemba's Group

texts.en:
Mary is the leader of the group of five women. She is 46 years old and married with 7 children, ages 10, 12, 16, 18, 20, 22, and 24. All of her children are in school. The community she lives in is semi urban.

Mary has been making and selling samosas at shops and schools for the last eight years. While the market for her food is large, a big challenge is the high cost of food items and transportation.

Mary plans on using this loan to purchase peas, oil, and wheat, the main ingredients she uses in her samosas. With the help of past loans she has received from MCDT, Mary has been able to pay school fees for all her children and ensure that her business continues to function.

Mary hopes to one day buy a house for her family.

Mary has successfully paid back 14 loans.

loans.use: Buying food items to make samosas to sell

loans.name: Thi Chinh's Group

texts.vi:
• Mrs. N. Thi Chinh (ID number: 060028), 31 years old, wants to borrow 120 USD to buy more products for her general store. Her husband sells eggs, earning stable income. She has 2 children who are still going to school. She likes to borrow money from this program because she can repay gradually. Her average income is 8-9 USD/day.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Dan (ID number: 060029), wants to borrow 120 USD to buy more hats and books to sell.
  • Mrs. M. Thi Lam (ID number: 060031), wants to borrow 120 USD to have more fund for business in waste metals.
  • Mrs. N. Thi M. (ID number: 060032), wants to borrow 120 USD to buy more products for her general store.
  • Mrs. T. Thi Hoa (ID number: 060033), wants to borrow 120 USD to do business in waste materials.

    Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

    Chị Nguyễn Thị Chỉnh (MS: 060028), năm nay 31 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để bổ sung vốn bán hàng tạp hóa. Chồng chị đi bán trứng có thu nhập thường xuyên. Chị có hai con nhỏ còn đang đi học. Chị rất thích tham gia vay vốn của chương trình vì được trả dần. Mức thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 120.000 VND/ngày.

  • Trong nhóm còn có :
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Dân (MS: 060029), vay 2.006.000 VND mua thêm mũ và sách vở bán.
  • Chị Mẫn Thị Lâm (MS: 060031), vay 2.006.000 VND bổ sung vốn buôn bán sắt vụn.
  • Chị Nguyễn Thị Mẫn (MS: 060032), vay 2.006.000 VND mua hàng tiêu dùng về bán.
  • Chị Trương Thị Hoa (MS: 060033), vay 2.006.000 VND để đi buôn bán phế liệu.

loans.use: general store, small businesses

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. is 25-years-old, married with one child. She lives in Benin City with her family. She is a hairdresser by training. She went to school for 12 months and she started her own salon business in 2004. She has been a LAPO client for the past 2 years. Kate is requesting the loan to purchase more hairdressing materials and weavons for resale.

loans.use: To buy more weavons and hairdressing materials for resale

loans.name: Florence Nanziri's Group

texts.en:
Florence N. is a 36 year old single mother of four children, ranging in ages from 3 to 18 years old. She has operated a grocery in her neighborhood for the past 15 years, selling fruits and vegetables and other products. Florence first started the grocery because there weren’t any in her neighborhood. She started with just a few items, such as tomatoes and bananas, and gradually expanded her business to include more items.

Twice a week, Florence goes off early in the morning to the Owino Market, a large outdoor market near downtown Kampala, and buys about 150,000 (Ugandan shillings) or roughly $90 (US dollars) worth of produce. She transports the goods back to her grocery stall via motorcycle taxi (boda boda) or minibus taxi (matatu).

Being the first grocery to open in her neighborhood guaranteed Florence would have many customers, although there are now other groceries nearby. Florence's grocery is open seven days a week from 8:00 AM in the morning until 9:00 PM at night, except on Sunday when she opens at 9:00 AM after attending mass. She is helped by her sister who also works at the grocery.

Florence uses the profits from her business to pay school fees for her children. Profits are getting smaller as food prices go up. Florence has struggled to pay loans back in the face of unexpected expenses, but as she has been a member of MCDT for the last three years, she and her group have been able to repay approximately nine loans. Florence says that the loans make her life better, helping her to overcome challenges, in particular the school fees.

Florence currently lives in a house with three rooms, but she would like to build a larger house with five rooms. Her ultimate goal with a larger loan and sufficient savings is to build a bigger house for her family.

For now, with this new loan, Florence would like to buy a refrigerator. This will help her business because she will be able to sell cold drinks in addition to the produce she sells.

loans.use: Purchase a refrigerator to sell cold drinks

loans.name: Pauline Kose's Group

texts.en:
Pauline K. is the leader of a group of four women. She is 37 and divorced with four children. Her eldest child is 18 years old and her youngest is 12. All of her children are in school. Pauline lives in a semi-urban slum on the outskirts of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Pauline has been selling produce for the past eight years. She primarily sells tomatoes, bananas, and matoke (a green banana that is a staple part of the Ugandan diet). Her clients are mainly local people who shop for food for their families.

Pauline plans on using this loan to purchase more produce so she can be more competitive and increase profits. Additional profits will help Pauline pay the rent for her business, her residence, and the school fees for her children. She hopes to one day be able to send her children for a university level education.

Pauline has successfully paid back three loans to MCDT.

loans.use: Increase stock of produce

loans.name: Tamaraneh Ii Group

texts.en:
This group is called Tamaraneh II. Its members are Mariama J. and Mariama F.. The former sells groceries and the latter sells garas (tie-dyed cloth) and foodstuffs. They both have been with SMT for many years now and SMT loans have been of vital importance in their lives. It helps them solve their kids' schooling problems and in the running of their homes.

Now that they have finished repayment with SMT, they are again requesting a new loan of US$ 500.

Mariama J. who is the leader of this group was born in Massingbi but now resides in Makeni town together with her husband and 7 children. Her husband is a teacher with a very low salary which means Mariama J. has to contribute immensely towards the family`s well being.

loans.use: Buy more  foodstuffs and bales of cotton

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Amina Kibirige's Group

texts.en:
Amina K. is the leader of a group of five women. She is 37 years old and is married with three children. The oldest child is five years old and is in primary school while the youngest is not yet in school. The community she lives and works in is an urban slum within a low-lying area that often floods during the rainy season.

Amina takes public transportation to town to purchase her goods and then uses luggage lifters to carry the products to her shop. Her shop is located near a school, so her primary customers are students.

Amina's two main challenges are the fluctuating costs associated with her products and the school holidays when her business is slower because of fewer customers.

Amina has been with MCDT since 2002 and has successfully paid back 18 loans. With these loans she has expanded her business a great deal and can now sustain herself and pay her children’s school fees. In addition, she has been able to construct a house for her family and has recently expanded her business to include a saloon.

Amina hopes to be able to finish construction on her house and to one day expand her saloon. This loan will help towards that goal.

loans.use: Increase retail stock

loans.name: Ayawavi Thérèse

texts.fr:
Ayawavi Thérèse S. was born in Lomé and is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. Her business is selling necessary commodities in Lomé. She began her business in 1994. In her store, she sells mineral water, milk, butter and canned goods. This first loan will allow her to restock her supply in order to free up her consistent incoming revenues.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Agée de 40 ans, S. Ayawavi Thérèse est née à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle a pour activité principale la vente des produits de premières nécessités à Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 1994. Dans son magasin elle vend de l’eau minérale, le lait, le beurre, les boîtes de conserve etc. Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de refaire son stock afin de dégager des revenus consistants.

loans.use: Buy general grocery products

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Originating from Notsé, a city situated 100 kilometers from Lomé, Mr. Kodjo D. was born on December 31, 1984 and is single. After having finished his studies, he began a business selling secondhand clothing in the Attikoumé district of Lomé. This business, which he began in 2006 with a small investment, has grown so much that he can not keep up with the customer demand. This first loan will allow him to buy four bundles of secondhand clothing in order to improve his sales.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Originaire de Notsè, ville située à 100 KM de Lomé, Monsieur D. Kodjo est né le 31 décembre 1984 et est célibataire. Après avoir cessé ses études, il s’est lancé dans le commerce de friperie dans le grand quartier d’Attikoumé à Lomé. Ce commerce qu’il a commencé depuis 2006 avec une petite somme grandit aujourd’hui de telle sorte qu’il n’arrive plus à satisfaire tous ses clients. Ce premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acheter quatre ballots de friperie afin d’améliorer sa vente.

loans.use: Buy four bundles of secondhand clothing

loans.name: Christine Kiwanuka's Group

texts.en:
Christine K. is the leader of a group of five women. She is 48 years old and is married with six children. Her eldest child is 20 years old and her youngest is 8 years old. All of her children are in school. Christine lives in a semi-urban slum on the outskirts of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Christine has operated her retail shop for the past ten years. Her customers are mainly local people with families. Christine's biggest challenges are having only a few customers (who typically only buy small things) and the high cost of products.

Christine plans on using this loan to increase her stock by purchasing wholesale and to install piped water in her home. Christine will then be able to sell more products, including water, and increase her profits. With the profits, Christine will continue to pay school fees. She hopes to eventually be able to afford to buy a motorcycle to rent out and to purchase a refrigerator to sell cold drinks.

Christine has successfully paid back seven loans to MCDT. It is through these loans that she has been able to keep her children in school and install electricity.

loans.use: Increase stock and install piped water

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Akossiwa Djigbodi

texts.fr:
Born on July 20, 1975 in Lomé, Ms. Akossiwa Djigbodi F. is a single woman who is a hairdresser by trade. She opened her own hair salon “Divine Coiffure” in the Lomé suburb of Adidogomé. Since the opening of this salon in 1998, Ms. F. has had many customers who were, for the most part, female civil servants. She runs her business in a professional manner and always gains the trust of her customers. This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to buy hair relaxer, 4 boxes of hair coloring caps, and some hair weaves.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Née le 20 juillet 1975 à Lomé, Mademoiselle F. Akossiwa Djigbodi est une femme célibataire qui est coiffeuse de profession. Elle a ouvert son atelier de coiffure « DIVINE COIFFURE » dans le quartier d’Adidogomé. Depuis l’ouverture de cet atelier en 1998 elle accueille beaucoup de clients qui sont pour la plupart des femmes fonctionnaires. Elle exerce son activité avec beaucoup de professionnalisme et gagne toujours la confiance de ses clients. Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter de défrisant, 4 cartons de mèche et des tissages.

loans.use: Purchase of hair coloring caps and hair weaves

loans.name: Teopista Namuli's Group

texts.en:
Teopista N. is the leader of a group of four women. She is 45 years old and is divorced with five children. Her oldest child is 23 years old and her youngest is 10 years old. All of her children are in school. Teopista lives in a semi-urban slum on the outskirts of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Teopista has a stall in Makawa Market and has sold her goods to people that visit the market for the past 20 years. She faces the difficulties of high transportation costs, high produce costs, and intense competition.

Teopista plans on using this loan to increase her stock of produce and to pay for her children's school fees. With the profits, Teopista will be able to maintain her current customers and increase her income. Teopista hopes to one day afford a refrigerator so she can start another business, increasing profits while continuing to support her family.

Teopista has successfully paid back seven loans to MCDT. It is through these loans that she has been able to keep her children in school and tend to the needs of her family.

loans.use: To increase stock of produce

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Adzo

texts.fr:
Mrs. Adzo L. was born June 2, 1985 in Lomé. She is married to Mr. Simone Yibo who is an auto electrician and who therefore has sporadic income. Mrs. L. has two children and contributes to her household’s expenses. She is a hairdresser and has opened a hair salon called “Coiffure Confidence” in the Lomé suburb of Adidogomé. This is her first loan and she is requesting it so she can buy 5 boxes of hair coloring caps, 8 hair weaves, and some hair relaxer.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Madame L. Adzo est née le 02 juin 1985 à Lomé. Elle s’est mariée à monsieur YIBO Simone qui est un électricien Auto donc a un revenu irrégulier. Elle a deux enfants et contribue aux dépenses de sa famille. Elle est coiffeuse et a ouvert un salon de coiffure « COIFFURE CONFIDENCE » dans le quartier d’Adidogomé. Elle sollicite pour la première fois ce prêt pour acheter 5 cartons de mèches, 8 tissages et de défrisant.

loans.use: Purchase of hair coloring caps and hair weaves

loans.name: Yawovi

texts.fr:
Mr. Yawovi A. was born on December 8, 1983 in Tové-Agbéssia in the Kloto prefecture. He is married and has two children. He is an electrician by trade, but since 2003 he has been involved in the buying and selling of cereals and canned tomatoes. This has provided him with a good source of income because some of his clients are restaurant owners who always buy from him and pay him three days after he purchases his goods. Now his client base is expanding and he wants to keep up with demand, so he has requested this loan to buy 15 boxes of tomatoes and two sacks of corn.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur A. Yawovi est né le 08 décembre 1983 à Tové-Agbéssia dans la préfecture de Kloto. Il est marié et père de deux enfants. Il est électronicien de profession mais depuis l’année 2003, il s’est lancé dans le commerce de céréales et de tomates en boîte. Ce commerce lui procure de bons revenus car il a des clients qui sont des restauratrices qui achètent et payent chaque trois jours qui suivent l’achat. Aujourd’hui sa clientèle s’élargit et il désire la satisfaire ce qui l’amène à solliciter ce prêt pour acheter 15 cartons de tomates et deux sacs de maïs.

loans.use: Purchase of 15 boxes of tomatoes

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: This is Isatu S.. She has been in the salt/pepper/onions/tomatoes business for the past 9 years now. Isatu is 35; she was born in Moyamba District but now lives with her husband and 3 children in Makeni. Her husband works as a security officer and receives a very small salary, hardly enough to cater for even his own personal needs. Isatu contributes tremendously towards the family`s welfare. Isatu is seeking a loan of US$ 250 to add onto her business.

loans.use: Increase on the size of her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bonkapri

texts.en:
This is Bonkapri K.. She is requesting a loan of US$ 300 to add on to to her current stock.

Bonkapri was born in Malal about 60 miles away from Makeni, some 40 years ago. She now lives with her husband and their 2 children here in Makeni. For over 6 years now, Bonkapri has been selling palm oil; from that business she is able to manage her affairs together with those of her children and relatives back home in Malal.

loans.use: Buy more gallons of palm oil to expand  her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rehema Musoke's Group

texts.en:
Rehema M. is 45 years old and is married with six children. She lives in the Triangle Zone of Mulago Hill in Kampala. Her children range in ages from 15 to 30 years old, and the youngest three children are in school. Her middle daughter, aged 18, is in year S6, her final year of secondary education. With a Kiva loan, Rehema will be able to enroll her daughter in a vocational course after she graduates, allowing her to obtain productive employment.

Rehema sells bunches of green bananas used to make matooke, a steamed and mashed banana dish, slightly denser than mashed potatoes that is a staple of the Ugandan diet. It is served with beans or meat in a sauce that flavors the matooke. Twice a week, Rehema leaves Kampala around 5:00 AM in the morning to travel by public taxi (a minivan that holds 14 people) to Mbarara to purchase the matooke. Arriving at midday, she frequents different vendors to get the best deals she can find. She purchases 50 bags, stuffed with bunches of bananas, for 2,500 (Ugandan shillings) or $1.50 (US dollars). She also arranges for her wares to be transported by truck for 25,000 (Ugandan shillings) or $15 (US dollars), spending the night in Balala before returning the following morning.

Rehema sells the matooke in Kampala at the Kalerwe Market, a large outdoor market that sells all sorts of produce and goods. By the end of the day, there is often none left. Other times, she sells the remaining matooke to the women staying at the market.

Rehema can make a profit of about 50,000 (Ugandan shillings) or about $30 (US dollars), equal to 1000 (Ugandan shillings) per bag on each shipment. Rehema has been in this business for about 15 years. She says it’s a business she knows well because she understands how to buy everything she needs to make it run. The major challenge is getting and paying for transport.

Rehema has been a member of MCDT for six years and has received approximately 12 loans. These loans have helped to pay for her children's school fees. The extra profit she is able to save is helping her to prepare a house for her family. With this new loan, she will be able to pass this success on to the next generation.

loans.use: Grow business to help pay for school fees

loans.name: Florence Bogere's Group

texts.en:
Florence is the leader of a five-member group. She is 42 and married with 6 children. All of them are in school. The community she lives and works in is semi-urban and a slum in a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season. Her main challenges are the floods from the rainy season as well as the long distance she has to travel to get some of her products.

Florence has been selling beer and sodas for six years and sells her products in small quantities to those who come by. She plans on using this loan to increase her stock of "waragi," a local alcohol that she sells. By purchasing larger quantities of waragi at a time, she will be able to reduce her transportation costs and time wastage.

Florence plans to use the additional income for school fees for her children. Her future plans include buying a plot of land and building a house for her children.

Florence has successfully paid back 19 loans during her time with MCDT.

loans.use: Increase stock for her bar

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 22, 2008)
